1 APRIL.part2: What Shall We Then Say to These Things?
1 APRIL.part4: What shall we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be against us?
1 APRIL.part5:
What are "these things" that Paul was alluding to? "These things" denote not just the redemptive work that God has done for us through His Son, our Lord Jesus [v. 29-30], but also all that He has promised to do for us who have been adopted into His family.

The phrase "these things" is all-encompassing. Paul, in his other epistles, uses a similar phrase - "all things" [see Romans 8:28, 37; 1 Corinthians 3:21]. "These things" point to God the Father in all His power, perfection, purposes and providence. It points to God the Son, in His redemptive work and ministerial intercession. It further points to God the Holy Spirit in His regenerating work, His sealing, His comfort and His convicting.

The work of salvation has opened for us the floodgate of God's blessings. As God's elect, we are kept under the canopy of God's loving care in all that we face - the world, life and death, the good days and bad ones, success and failure, health and illness, peace and turmoil.

Peter puts it thus: "According as his divine power hath given unto us all things that pertain unto life and godliness, through the knowledge of him that hath called us to glory and virtue" [2 Peter 1:3]. What a promise! Though fraught we may be with challenges, yet we are not left helpless. So we go through life assured of God's saving grace, confident of His tender mercies, and certain that His providence, purpose and promise will always be for our eternal good. Hence, there is nothing that should faze us because "if God be for us, who can be against us?"
1 APRIL.part7: If God be for us, who can be against us? Do not pray that God will be on your side. Pray rather that you will be on His side.

2 APRIL.part2: What Shall We Then Say to These Things?  If God be for Us ...
2 APRIL.part4: What shall we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be against us?
2 APRIL.part5:
A great challenge faces the Christian. Our Lord Jesus warned us: "In the world ye shall have tribulation" [John 16:33; Matthew 5:11]. The apostles, in the course of their ministry gave similar warnings: "Beloved, think it not strange concerning the fiery trial which is to try you, as though some strange thing happened unto you" [1 Peter 4:12]. That "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:22]. "All that will live godly in Christ Jesus shall suffer persecution" [2 Timothy 3:12].

We know that our enemies are manifold - the devil's snares and fiery darts, the world's ideas and vain philosophies, and the weaknesses of our own flesh. If we were to allow our own experiences to answer the question, we would surely be defeated. And when we are tempted to throw up our hands in despair, Paul puts forth five rhetorical questions; the first of which is: "If God be for us, who can be against us?"

These questions are designed to help believers deal with the fears that often lodge in our minds when our lives turn south. These questions help us to see the absurdity of the notion that God is unable to preserve and provide for those whom He has redeemed. Paul is reminding us we can be confident that "He which hath begun a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ" [Philippians 1:6].

"If God be for us, who can be against us?" is also the great promise of God that He orchestrates all events for good to those who are called according to His purpose [v. 28].
2 APRIL.part7:
"Through many dangers, toils and snares
I have already come
'Tis grace has brought me safe thus far
and grace will lead me home."
If you have committed your soul to God, you can be sure that He will bring you safely Home.

3 APRIL.part2: He Spared Not His Own Son...
3 APRIL.part4: He that spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for us all, how shall he not with him also freely give us all things?
3 APRIL.part5:
On Mount Moriah, just as Abraham was about to plunge the knife into his son, God provided a ram as a substitute for Isaac [Genesis 22:13]. Abraham called the place Jehovah-jireh [Genesis 22:14] - the LORD provides. Some 2,000 years later, God made a similar substitute, not for one man but for all mankind, not with a ram but a lamb - the Lamb of God.

God who spared not His own Son, shall also with Him freely give us all things. The "all things" pertains to our life - the air we breathe, the water we drink, the food we consume, the blessings we receive out of His hand daily. The "all things" are limitless. God gives generously out of an endless supply. As the hymnwriter says, "His love has no limit, His grace has no measure, His power has no boundary known unto men; For out of His infinite riches in Jesus, He giveth and giveth and giveth again." God never runs low on resources. However, there is one thing with God that is not inexhaustible - His Son, His one and only Son.

There are philanthropists who have given billions of dollars to sundry causes, but however much they have given, they can never do what God has done. It is one thing to give things, even very valuable things generously for the wellbeing of others, it is quite another to give the life of one you deeply love, which is what God did. The most generous and loving act of God was to send His Son. And the Son in turn gave His life to redeem us from our sins.
3 APRIL.part7: "For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son ..." [John 3:16]. The Son so loved us that He gave His life.

4 APRIL.part4: He that spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for us all, how shall he not with him also freely give us all things?
4 APRIL.part5:
Many parents are heartbroken when they see their sons being sent off to Basic Military Training. The scenes of tearful albeit temporary separation in no way compare with what God the Father did to His only begotten Son - the Father spared not His Son.

The Father spared not the Son from the lowest birth. The Son was born in a manger surrounded by cattle and shepherds. The Father spared not the Son from the humiliation of a menial profession, the sweat of His brow and the calluses of a carpenter's hands. The Father spared not the Son from the temptation of the devil. The Father spared not the Son from His own people's rejection. "He came unto his own, and his own received him not" [John 1:11]. The Father spared not the Son from the bigotry of the religious elite and He was thrown out of the synagogue.

The Father spared not the Son from the wickedness of a fallen world. He was "despised and rejected of men; a man of sorrows, and acquainted with grief ... (He was) smitten of God, and afflicted ... He was wounded for our transgressions, He was bruised for our iniquities ... He was oppressed, and He was afflicted ... He was brought as a lamb to the slaughter ..." [Isaiah 53:3-7]. The world laughed at Him, spat upon Him and ridiculed Him.

The Father spared not the Son from trials, temptations, agony, even the agony of the cruel cross. He spared not His Son from abandonment [Matthew 27:46]. He spared not the Son from death and the tomb.

God "spared not his own Son but delivered Him up for us." That is our salvation and hope, and our assurance forever.
4 APRIL.part7: We will not have any heartache that has not first pierced His heart for God spared not His own Son. We will have no burden that our Lord Jesus did not bear first.

5 APRIL.part4: He that spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for us all, how shall he not with him also freely give us all things?
5 APRIL.part5:
In verse 32, we see the incalculable evil of sin, and the infinite justice of God. We see also the severity of God, and the immeasurable goodness of God in sparing not His own Son in order to redeem us.

Here, Paul argues from the greatest to the least. Our Lord Jesus told the disciples that God "knoweth that ye have need of all these things" [Matthew 6:32]. In fact, the heavenly Father knows our needs even before we ask him [Matthew 6:8]. These "things" are the necessities of life. Paul is arguing that God, having given us His only begotten Son, "how shall He not with (God the Son) also freely give us all things?"

God the Father has committed His Son, and when Jesus Christ undertook our cause to be born of a woman, to take on "the likeness of sinful flesh" [v. 3], and take upon Himself the sins of the world, we realise that all we need for this life is secondary. The indisputable logic of God's act of love should assure us that there is neither person nor circumstance that should shake our faith.

If we would trust God for eternal salvation - that blessed prospect which we know only by faith - would we not trust Him when it comes to matters dealing with our life on earth? Therefore, when we fret about earthly things, turn our minds toward God's incomprehensible love for us - He spared not His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all - and we ask, "Would God the Father not honour His promise? Could God the Son have died in vain?" And the answer is assuredly no!
5 APRIL.part7:
The soul that on Jesus has leaned for repose,
I will not, I will not desert to its foes.
That soul, though all hell should endeavor to shake,
I'll never, no never, no never forsake.

6 APRIL.part3: VERSE 33 "Judgement came upon all men to condemnation"
6 APRIL.part7: Who shall lay any thing to the charge of God's elect? It is God that justifieth.  THOUGHT  t has been over two thousand years since our Lord Jesus went to the cross to be crucified for our sins. The accusations against God's elect however, continue till today. "Who shall lay any thing to the charge of God's elect?" From whence do the charges come? From several sources: We are charged with Adam's sin. When he fell, all mankind fell with him. By his sin, "judgment came upon all men to condemnation" [Romans 5:18]. We are also charged with our own sins and lack of righteousness because we have "all gone out of the way, (we) are together become unprofitable; there is none that doeth good, no, not one" [Romans 3:12]. We have committed a multitude of sins both before and after conversion. Our conscience also bears witness against us. Satan, the accuser of the brethren, accuses us before God day and night [see Revelation 12:10]. What is the answer to these charges? Christ has paid the debt of our sin in full. If Christ has paid it all, then nothing can be charged and no one can charge anything to our account. Since Christ has paid it all, these charges avail nothing because they have all been answered in Christ. In Christ, our sins are pardoned and we are imputed with His perfect righteousness. On account of His atoning work on the cross, God's justice has been totally satisfied. God justified in one place, in one time, in one sacrifice, all those He has purposed to save. It is God who justifies and no charge and no accuser can change God's mind. What good news this is, and what assurance God has given us. Jesus paid it all, All to Him I owe; Sin had left a crimson stain, He washed it white as snow. - Elvina M. Hall

7 APRIL.part7: Who shall lay any thing to the charge of God's elect? It is God that justifieth.  THOUGHT  n the closing verses of Romans 8, Paul poses a series of questions. In verse 33, the question is: "Who shall lay any thing to the charge of God's elect?" This is a legal question. In a law court, who has authority to bring charges against another person? This question involves several presuppositions. It presupposes that there is an objective standard of righteousness. It presupposes that the person who has been charged has done something wrong. In the court of heaven, it has been established without doubt that we are sinners [Romans 3:23]. We are guilty as charged of breaking God's law. Will the charges stick? Absolutely. Are we condemned? Most certainly. The soul that sinneth shall die [Ezekiel 18:4, 30]. How does a sinner escape these charges? Will the love of the judge be enough to let a repeat offender off without consequences? That is inconceivable. God is good and loving, but also perfectly just. That is our problem. We are neither good nor righteous because we have violated God's Word. Our sin hauls us into the court and presence of the perfectly righteous Judge. This is really bad news for sinners. We cannot get off on a technicality. There is no loophole for us to wiggle out of our sin. God sees everything and "all things are naked and opened unto the eyes of Him with whom we have to do" [Hebrews 4:13]. He will never let us off with a reduced sentence. We should expect nothing less than the full weight of God's judgment upon us. The only hope for sinners is that another person will bear the wrath of God on our behalf. That person is Jesus Christ. For (God the Father) hath made (God the Son) to be sin for us, who knew no sin; that we might be made the righteousness of God in Him. - 2 Corinthians 5:21

8 APRIL.part7: Who shall lay any thing to the charge of God's elect? It is God that justifieth.  THOUGHT  o justify is to declare someone not just innocent but also righteous. Put another way, to justify is a legal pronouncement that someone is in full accordance with God's law. He is not just acquitted of all charges, he is also freed from all judgment. If we keep God's law, we will be justified. But sinners are caught in a double bind. Not only do we not keep, we are also unable to keep God's law and lawbreakers must be punished because God has said, "I will not justify the wicked" [Exodus 23:7; 34:7]. So we are guilty and it would be against God's very nature to let sinners go unpunished for He has said, the man who "justifieth the wicked, and he that condemneth the just ... both are abomination to the LORD" [Proverbs 17:15]. It is inconceivable that God would do what He Himself has called an abomination. Yet we read that "it is God that justifieth". Is it a contradiction? Absolutely not! For God to justify, sinners must be punished. Divine justification is not meted out at the cost of nothing. The circle is squared through the substitutionary atonement of Christ. Paul writes that God is "just, and the justifier of (the sinner) which believeth in Jesus" [Romans 3:26]. Jesus Christ "Who his own self bare our sins in his own body on the tree" [1 Peter 2:24] takes our place at the judgment hall so that God is just and still justifies sinners.  Justification by faith in Christ alone is the main hinge on which the Christian faith turns (adapted from John Calvin).

9 APRIL.part7: Who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died, yea rather, that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us.  THOUGHT  omans 8:34 asks another rhetorical question - "Who is he that condemneth?" There is no one in heaven, on earth, or in hell who has the right to condemn the true believer. The only Person who might have the power to condemn us is Jesus Christ, the eternal Son of God. If Jesus were not God, He would not have the power to judge. But the Father "hath committed all judgment unto the Son" [John 5:22]. Christ is "ordained of God to be the Judge of quick and dead" [Acts 10:42]. And in His hand is the fan of judgment with which "He will throughly purge His floor, and gather His wheat into the garner; but He will burn up the chaff with unquenchable fire" [Matthew 3:12; 19:28; Acts 17:31; Romans 14:10; 2 Timothy 4:1]. Christ alone has power to judge the world. However, there are things which He has done and is now doing that make it impossible for Him to condemn us. It is inconceivable He will condemn the person who comes to Him by faith and trusts him for salvation. This blessed truth is given a double assurance because Christ went to the cross to pay the penalty for the sins of the elect, and He rose again to secure the salvation of those who believe in Him. There is no way that Jesus - who died for His sheep, was raised to life for their justification, has ascended into heaven, and is now interceding for them - who has done such things for His people will turn around and condemn them. That would make His sacrifice on the cross farcical, and render our faith in Him most miserable.  Kiss the Son, lest He be angry, and ye perish from the way, when His wrath is kindled but a little. Blessed are all they that put their trust in Him. - Psalm 2:12

10 APRIL.part7: Who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died, yea rather, that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us.  THOUGHT  aul gives three reasons why Christ would not judge us even though He is the One who will separate the sheep from the goats and the wheat from the tares [Matthew 25:31-34]. The first reason is that Christ died for us. Why did He die? He died in order to make full payment for the sins of all who trust in Him. God has set forth Christ "to be a propitiation through faith in His blood ... for the remission of sins" [Romans 3:25]. A propitiation is a sacrifice which turns away wrath. God is justly displeased with us because of our sin, but His wrath was turned away from us onto His Son. As Christ was nailed to the cross, God's wrath was fully spent upon Him, so that there is none left to be spent on the person who trusts in Christ. Isaiah says it is God "that pleadeth the cause of His people, Behold, I have taken out of thine hand the cup of trembling, even the dregs of the cup of my fury; thou shalt no more drink it again" [Isaiah 51:22]. Paul reminds us "Christ died for the ungodly ... Christ died for us" [Romans 5:6-8]. Who is the "us"? The "us" are those who belong to Christ; those whom the Father gave to His Son before the foundation of the world; those who are His sheep [John 10:14-15]. The Father condemned the Son for the sin that is in us. That sin, having been condemned 2,000 years ago on Calvary cannot be condemned again. The fact that the One who will judge is the very same Person who made the payment for our sins upon the Cross means that He cannot possibly condemn us.  The cup of wrath which Christ drank to the last drop becomes the cup of blessing for us [1 Corinthians 10:16].

11 APRIL.part7: Who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died, yea rather, that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us.  THOUGHT  aul's second reason why Christ will not condemn the elect is that He is risen again. The resurrection of Jesus Christ is a historically verifiable fact. The empty tomb, His multiple appearances over forty days and to hundreds of people, the radical change in the apostles from fear and dejection to boldness in testimony, the downpouring of the Holy Spirit and the rapid growth of the church in spite of severe persecution all point to the fact that Christ did indeed rise from the dead. There is no other way of knowing if what Christ did on the Cross has been accepted by the Father other than His resurrection from the dead. The resurrection meant that the Father has accepted the sacrifice of the Son, and that what He did on the Cross was enough to pay for our sins in full. Paul says that Christ "was delivered for our offences, and was raised again for our justification" [Romans 4:25]. This means that Jesus was given over to the power of death for our sins, but He was resurrected from the dead for our justification. Because He was raised, we are justified, no longer condemned; instead, we are declared righteous in God's sight. Not only is Christ risen from the dead, He is also given a place of honour at the right hand of God, with all authority in heaven and earth. The amazing blessing is that we who are in Christ are united with Him, raised up with Him, and seated with Him in heavenly places [Ephesians 2:4-7]. That I pray, is your hope and assurance!  Hear the news, sinner, free! free! free! Why not believe it? 'Tis good news for thee. Jesus the Just One has died on the tree, Died for guilty sinners, and "Salvation is free."

12 APRIL.part7: Who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died, yea rather, that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us.  THOUGHT  aul's third reason why believers will not be condemned is that our Lord Jesus, who has been raised from the dead and seated at the right hand of God, is also interceding for us. In the original language this is a compound word which means "to plead with someone". In Romans 8:26, Paul tells us that the Holy Spirit "maketh intercession for us". The connotation here is "to plead with someone for someone else" - the Holy Spirit pleading with God for us. The emphasis is that intercession is being made for the sake of another. This is what Christ is doing; He intercedes for us. The ministry of intercession is our Lord's high priestly ministry. In Old Testament times, the high priest not only offered a sacrifice for sins, he would go into the holy of holies, bearing the names of the twelve tribes of Israel on his breastplate and the blood of the sacrifice he had made. There, he would plead on behalf of the people for God to show them mercy. The ministry of the high priest in the Old Testament foreshadows the work of Christ. The writer of Hebrews says that "Christ being come an high priest of good things to come ... (not) by the blood of goats and calves, but by His own blood He entered in once into the holy place, having obtained eternal redemption for us" [Hebrews 9:11-12]. This is the present ministry of Christ. We do not travel through life alone. Christ walks with us. When we "walk in the light, as He is in the light, we have fellowship one with another" [1 John 1:7].  We never pray to God alone because Christ prays with and for us.

13 APRIL.part7: Who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died, yea rather, that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us.  THOUGHT  here are five great differences between the work of the high priest in Old Testament times and the ministry of Christ. First, the high priesthood of the Old Testament was a temporary priesthood; whereas Christ is "a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec" [Hebrews 7:17]. Second, the high priest entered an earthly tabernacle made with hands; whereas Christ entered the perfect and heavenly tabernacle [Hebrews 9:11, 24]. Third, the high priest entered the tabernacle by the blood of goats and calves, which could never take away sins; whereas Christ entered by His own blood [Hebrews 9:12; 10:4]. Fourth, the high priest had to offer sacrifices year after year; whereas Christ offered Himself once for all and obtained eternal redemption for us [Hebrews 9:12; 10:3, 10]. Fifth, the high priest stood throughout his ministry, but Christ "after He had offered one sacrifice for sins for ever, sat down on the right hand of God" [Hebrews 10:11-12], signifying that His work was done! Our Lord Jesus offered His own life and shed His own precious blood for us, and by His "one offering, He hath perfected for ever them that are sanctified" [Hebrews 10:14]. And we can be confident that He "is able also to save (sinners) to the uttermost that come unto God by Him, seeing He ever liveth to make intercession for them" [Hebrews 7:25]. Sin will never again stain and condemn the soul of the Christian because "if any man sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous" [1 John 2:1]. Before the throne of God above, I have a strong a perfect plea. A great high priest, whose name is love, Who ever lives and pleads for me. - Charitie L. de Chenez

14 APRIL.part7: Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?  THOUGHT  he Christian life is not a walk in the park in perfect weather where the breeze softly caresses your skin. More often than not, the opposite is true. The Christian's walk has its ups and downs; the pathway is narrow and punctured with pot-holes. Sometimes, it is mundane, even dull. At other times, there are steep inclines and hazardous obstacles - tribulation, distress, persecution, famine, nakedness, peril, or sword. Our life circumstances are not indicative of our spiritual state. Proverbs 24:16 says "a just man falleth seven times, and riseth up again: but the wicked shall fall into mischief." The wicked man falls, and the just (righteous) man falls; in fact, it appears that the just man falls many more times than the wicked. The measure of our spiritual well-being is our relationship with God, not what happens to us or how adept we are in overcoming life's obstacles. It is Christ and His love in our lives that keep us to Him. This verse is crafted as a rhetorical question. Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? The answer is that nothing will. The word "separate" is rendered "put asunder" (see Matthew 19:6; Mark 10:9) in Christ's instruction on divorce. "What therefore God hath joined together, let not man put asunder." Here is our heavenly Bridegroom who has vowed He will not leave us. When the devil whispers in your ear that God has abandoned you in your hour of need, remember this promise.  Let your conversation be without covetousness; and be content with such things as ye have: for he hath said, I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee. - Hebrews 13:5

15 APRIL.part7: Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?  THOUGHT  n Romans 8:35, Paul lists seven situations in which we may think we have been separated from the love of God. These are by no means exhaustive but they represent some of life's circumstances that may cause us to doubt God's love for us. In his hymn, Does Jesus Care?, Frank E. Graeff also paints for us some dark moments of life: Does Jesus care when my heart is pained Too deeply for mirth or song ... Does Jesus care when my way is dark With a nameless dread and fear ... Does Jesus care when I've tried and failed To resist some temptation strong ... Does Jesus care when I've said goodbye To the dearest on earth to me. But the refrain gives this reassurance: O yes, He cares - I know He cares! His heart is touched with my grief; When the days are weary, the long nights dreary, I know my Savior cares. Verse 35 begins with WHO - an interrogative pronoun of person - but Paul lists things in the answer. John Calvin points out that Paul "preferred ascribing personality to things without life, and for this end that he might send forth with us into the contest as many champions as there are of temptations to try our faith." Dear child of God, we must be prepared for the struggles of this life. Here is Paul forewarning us that we will face opposition in life, from creatures and afflictions without, and doubts within - our own weakened will and strength of conviction. But the love of God will protect His true child even from their wavering faith. Our union with God is not dependent on our power. Our faith is decreed in eternity past and is forged by the power of God's own almighty hand.

16 APRIL.part3: VERSE 35 those things that are without, that which cometh
16 APRIL.part7: Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?  THOUGHT  he seven-item list of ordeals in Romans 8:35 is not exhaustive and except for the "sword" which he would soon face, Paul personally experienced these trials and afflictions. He was neither exempted from them nor immune to the anxieties that accompanied these sufferings. He wrote that as a minister of Christ, he was "in labours more abundant, in stripes above measure, in prisons more frequent, in deaths oft ... Beside those things that are without, that which cometh upon me daily, the care of all the churches" [2 Corinthians 11:23-28]. Tribulation carries the idea of "being pressed" or "experiencing pressure". The word is used to describe the treading of grapes to crush them. Our Lord Jesus forewarns us: "In the world ye shall have tribulation" [John 16:33]. Paul says to believers that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:22]. Peter says that we ought not to be surprised "concerning the fiery trial which is to try you, as though some strange thing happened unto you" [1 Peter 4:12]. These words ought to prepare us for what is unavoidable in the believer's life. We are called to salvation to be "partakers of Christ's sufferings" [1 Peter 4:13; Philippians 3:10]. What then should be our response to tribulations? Be patient (endure) [1 Peter 2:20] and rejoice [1 Peter 4:13; Colossians 1:24]. Why should we rejoice and endure? For one, our Lord Jesus has "overcome the world" and all its tribulations [John 16:33]. Paul adds that our present affliction is light compared to the "far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory" [2 Corinthians 4:17]. Tribulation is a distinguishing mark of the Christian. Paul says, "From henceforth let no man trouble me: for I bear in my body the marks of the Lord Jesus" [Galatians 6:17].

17 APRIL.part7: Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?  THOUGHT  s Paul continues with his list of ordeals, the items become more specific. Famine here does not mean an occasional lack of food; rather it is a prolonged and continual deprivation that leads to weakness. Famine is symbolic of extreme hardship. Paul said that in the course of his ministry, he was in "weariness and painfulness, in watchings often, in hunger and thirst, in fastings often" [2 Corinthians 11:27]. In the New Testament, famine is also an apocalyptic sign of distress [Matthew 24:7; Mark 13:8; Luke 21:11; Revelation 6:8; 18:8]. As we approach the last day, famine will be a major concern for the world. Nakedness is also another sign of extreme hardship. It means being exposed to nature's elements - cold and heat [2 Corinthians 11:27]. Peril denotes dangers or threatening circumstances not due to one's bravado as those who engage in extreme sports. In Romans 8:35, the peril is due to a person's faith and devotion to Christ. In 2 Corinthians 11:26, Paul's reference to perils he encountered served as a rebuke to those who questioned the authenticity of his apostleship and ministry. The ultimate peril is the sword. In the New Testament, the sword can literally mean a weapon, or figuratively denote authority [Romans 13:4]. In Romans 8:35, it highlights the extreme violence believers may face. With reference to Paul, it is the executioner's sword. The lesson here is that as far as the believer is concerned, even in physical death, the separation of the soul from the body, there will be no separation of his soul from Christ. We are kept by and in Him. We are safe in His hands. I give unto them eternal life; and they shall never perish, neither shall any man pluck them out of my hand. My Father, which gave them me, is greater than all; and no man is able to pluck them out of my Father's hand. - John 10:28-29

18 APRIL.part7: As it is written, For thy sake we are killed all the day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter.  THOUGHT  ... killed all the day long; ... sheep for the slaughter." What a dreadful prospect. Our Lord says, "In the world ye shall have tribulation" [John 16:33]. Luke informs that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:22]. Paul warns Timothy, "all that will live godly in Christ Jesus shall suffer persecution" [2 Timothy 3:12]. Affliction, banishment, ostracism - these are hardly selling points for convincing sinners to follow Christ, and thus begs the question: Is it worth following Christ? Is the Christian faith good for our well-being, our marriages, and our families? The answer from testimonies of truly born-again believers has always been an emphatic "yes". Polycarp, when given the opportunity to recant his faith in Christ or be burnt at the stake, declared without hesitation, "Eighty and six years I have served Him, and He has done me no wrong. How then can I blaspheme my King and Savior?" His final words were "I bless you, Father, for judging me worthy of this hour, so that in the company of the martyrs I may share the cup of Christ." Over the centuries, many faithful believers have suffered and some were put to death for their faith in Christ. The motivating factor comes down to one single point - Christ or the world? The Apostle Peter was engaged in a similar cost-benefit analysis, when he asked Jesus, "Behold, we have forsaken all, and followed thee; what shall we have therefore?" [Matthew 19:27]. Jesus replied, "Every one that hath forsaken houses, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, for my name's sake, shall receive an hundredfold, and shall inherit everlasting life" [Matthew 19:29]. It will be worth it all when we see Jesus! Life's trials will seem so small when we see Christ. One glimpse of his dear face, all sorrow will erase. So, bravely run the race till we see Christ. - Esther Kerr Rusthoi

In the context of Paul's statement "For thy sake we are killed all the day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter", it was not faithlessness that brought on the trials. Rather, it was because of their faithfulness that they were accounted as sheep for the slaughter. They suffered for Christ's sake. That begs the question we asked yesterday: Does being faithful to Christ work? Does being faithful to Christ make your life better? Some see the Christian faith as beneficial only after death. Others - those who preach a prosperity Gospel - see faith in Christ as the immediate panacea for all human sorrows; if you have enough faith, you will be happy and healthy here and now. The former surrenders the present to the devil and sees life on earth as just gritting the teeth, hanging on and waiting for heaven. The latter, on the other hand, imagines the immediate overthrow of evil and darkness. Both views are erroneous. The lens through which Paul viewed his own sufferings are expressed in his words to the Philippians, "I would ye should understand, brethren, that the things which happened unto me have fallen out rather unto the furtherance of the gospel; so that my bonds in Christ are manifest in all the palace, and in all other places" (Philippians 1:12-13). Paul recognises that the blessing of the Gospel would require continual sacrifice on the part of the faithful. That is the biblical perspective on suffering. Jesus said that the man was born blind not because of his sins or his parents "but that the works of God should be made manifest in him" [John 9:3].

THOUGHT  uring the course of his ministry, Paul was scourged, imprisoned, stoned, shipwrecked, suffered hunger, thirst and cold; his life was constantly under threat from all quarters - friends and foes. "Victims" demand personal rights, Christians are called to duty - to go the second mile. "Victims" strive to get, Christians strive to give. "Victims" complain "I am offended"; Christians say, "I will very gladly spend and be spent for you; though the more abundantly I love you, the less I be loved". 23 APRIL.part7: Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us.  THOUGHT  ontinuing our thoughts on the pernicious danger of victimhood, it has been rightly pointed out that the primary concern of so-called victims is their own feelings. That means that even after the fall, man is able to act reasonably, and even unbelievers "know how to give good gifts unto (their) children" [Luke 11:13]. However, reasonable behaviour has been replaced by subjective and capricious feelings. And feelings have become the chief concern of people in our day. Having rejected God and His Word, reasonable and sensible behaviour which are part of the renewed mind of the new creature, have been supplanted by the baser parts of man. His appetites, passions, emotions and feelings now rule. Society at large has to adapt to accommodate the feelings of easily offended self-professed victims. The Christian church has also toned down biblical truth lest we offend some. Believers are neither - as Peter says - "natural brute beasts" that have no understanding and who will "utterly perish in their own corruption" [2 Peter 2:12], nor unfeeling creatures. The Christian faith is not a cold attachment to a set of doctrines. Rather it is a faith in Christ that combines our embrace of the Son of God and our affection and trust in Him, which in turn, motivates us to live holy lives. 24 APRIL.part7: For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come ...  THOUGHT  oming to the end of his lengthy discourse on the assurance of God's love for His elect, Paul sums up his thoughts with heart-stirring affirmation: "For I am persuaded, that (nothing and no one) shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord" [v. 38-39]. The word "persuaded" is also translated variously as "trust" [Matthew 27:43], "have confidence in" [Galatians 5:10; Philippians 1:6, 25; 2 Thessalonians 3:4]. In some cases, the passive verb is used [see Luke 20:6; 2 Timothy 1:5, 12]. In other instances, "to persuade" has the connotation of actively convincing others to believe [see 2 Corinthians 5:11]. In Romans 8:38, the word "persuade" is in the middle voice meaning that Paul is the agent of persuasion, and he himself was persuaded. This is an act of obedience. When Paul says "I am persuaded," he is affirming his faith and confidence in God as his Saviour through Christ, and nothing and no one will be able to pluck him out of God's hand. In spite of all he had gone through, Paul, with all of his heart and mind, said, "Lord, I have been brought to this place in my life so I am persuaded." What was Paul persuaded about? He was persuaded about the love of Christ being greater than everything he had faced before, than what he was facing now and what he might face in the future. This is the moment we should pause and examine our own faith. Are you persuaded of the love of Christ for you?  The love of Christ must transform the life of Christians.

25 APRIL.part3: VERSE 38 Paul had risked his life multiple times to preach
25 APRIL.part7: For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come ...  THOUGHT  o be persuaded is to be convinced by its truth and possess an inward certainty. In the context of Romans 8:38, Paul, based on his own experiences, had gone through a process of persuasion and reached a settled conclusion. Paul is not simply teaching truth; he is stating his conviction. He is retelling us the reasons for his unwavering faith in Christ and the transformation of his life. Paul had risked his life multiple times to preach the Gospel. When thrown into the dungeon, he would have had time to rethink his position. Perhaps doubts and questions would begin to set in. Paul had to know that what he was preaching was the absolute truth if he were to remain willing to die for it and ask others to be willing to do the same. His summary statement [v. 38-39] is his response to those questions. Paul was not a naive fool. He was able to lay out the whole presentation because he relied upon those truths for his own conviction and assurance. Paul had to know that the truth he was presenting was truly the truth to know that this faith was worth dying for. We need to know that as well. We need to be as convinced of God's love as Paul was. Only then can we live like he lived. This is the power of a living testimony. The litmus test is this: If someone were to look at our lives, what would they say we are persuaded about?  Let your lives speak so loud that no one needs to hear what you say.

Unlike Lot who chose the plain of Jordan because "it was well watered ... even as the garden of the LORD" [Genesis 13:10], Paul was not persuaded that the grass somewhere else was greener. Paul never presented his persuasion as a means of improving the quality and enjoyment in this life. Paul also never said it is worth being a Christian even if the claims of Christ are false. Quite the contrary, he said that "if in this life only we have hope in Christ, we are of all men most miserable" [1 Corinthians 15:19]. Christians would be the biggest fools if there is no eternal reward in heaven. Paul was persuaded that "neither death nor life ... shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord". In the context, Paul is speaking of physical death. For the Christian, death is not separation from God but union with Him. Paul says he was "willing rather to be absent from the body, and to be present with the Lord" [2 Corinthians 5:8]. For believers, death is a joyous prospect because we will be in the presence of God. Romans 8:38 also tells us that life's physical aspects in all its attractions and detractions cannot take away our communion with God. So in death or life, and all that happens between these two terminal points, we can be assured of God's abiding and unwavering love. For whether we live, we live unto the Lord; and whether we die, we die unto the Lord: whether we live therefore, or die, we are the Lord's. - Romans 14:8

THOUGHT  sing a couplet, Paul bookends our life as "things present" and "things to come". With regard to "things present", Paul was alluding to current circumstances. In Galatians, he speaks of "this present evil world" [Galatians 1:4]. With regard to "things to come", Paul is not talking about the things to come later in his life or things in the near future. Rather, he brings us into the distant future - to eternity. This dual concept of "things present" and "things to come" is illustrated in the story of Lazarus [Luke 16:19ff]. When he was alive, Lazarus was a poor beggar, afflicted with sores. The only comfort afforded him was the dogs licking his sores, and his only desire was to eat "the crumbs which fell from the rich man's table" [Luke 16:20-21]. His near future brought him neither relief nor hope. But upon death, he "was carried by the angels into Abraham's bosom" [Luke 16:22] - and eternal communion with God. The rich man also died, but he was suffering the torments of hell [Luke 16:23]. Lazarus' sufferings of things present did not separate him from the love of God, and the rich man's affluence could not bring him to God. And in things to come, the two men remained worlds apart. The destiny of Lazarus and the rich man should cause us to ponder about the things to come for us. Are you persuaded of Christ's love for you - the love that caused Him to go to the cross, lay down His life for our sins, save us, and bring us into Abraham's bosom to be in communion with Him for eternity? I pray you are fully persuaded of this blessed hope. God has promised, "Yea, I have loved thee with an everlasting love: therefore with lovingkindness have I drawn thee." [Jeremiah 31:3]

29 APRIL.part7: I say the truth in Christ, I lie not, my conscience also bearing me witness in the Holy Ghost  THOUGHT  fter eight chapters of deep theological and doctrinal truths on the doctrines of salvation and election, Paul in Romans 9 turns to a different topic - the future of the Jewish people and the state of the nation Israel in the world and their standing before God. This discourse will run for three chapters (Romans 9-11). They are sometimes described as a parenthesis because they seem unrelated to the preceding chapters. These three chapters have also sparked much debate amongst believers whether the church is the Israel of God. The Old Testament is unequivocally clear that the Jews were God's chosen people. Moses writes: "For thou art an holy people unto the LORD thy God: the LORD thy God hath chosen thee to be a special people unto himself, above all people that are upon the face of the earth [Deuteronomy 7:68]. God promised to bless them and to bless all nations through them. But they rejected Christ. "He came unto his own, and his own received him not" [John 1:11]. In light of the Jews' rejection of Christ, did God's purpose to bless the Jews fail? And, if God's purpose for the Jews failed, what assurance do we have that His promise and purpose to save us will succeed? In other words, how do we know that nothing will separate us as His chosen people from His love in Christ? The simple answer is NO; God's plan will never fail. God has delivered His people in the past. He continues to preserve His people in the present, and He will restore the nation of Israel in the days to come. This truth is just as applicable to the nation as it is to the person. God is not done with you. His plan is still on track, and His plan will be fulfilled precisely as He has always intended.

THOUGHT  o prove that God is faithful in keeping His promises we need to know a few things. Firstly, what is God's covenant promise to Israel through Abraham?
