1 MAY.part7: I say the truth in Christ, I lie not, my conscience also bearing me witness in the Holy Ghost.  THOUGHT  hy did Paul emphasize that he was speaking the truth? Did not the Scriptures teach to "let your yea be yea; and your nay, nay" [James 5:12b]. Indeed. That said, Paul found it extremely difficult coming to terms with his fellow Jews being without Christ. In verse 2, Paul lamented "I have great heaviness and continual sorrow in my heart." Paul knew that the Jews were without Christ - they had rejected Him. But why would they be so steeped in unbelief to reject their Messiah? They were greatly privileged to be custodians of the Truth. God by His grace set them apart for Himself as a special people so that they might worship Him and bear witness of Him to all the earth. Israel was given the Law and Temple services, and promises of the Scriptures so that all peoples through them might know the One True Holy Living God. But instead of serving the Lord in humility and proclaiming Him, Israel put themselves above others. Blinded by their pride, they rejected Christ. Consequently, unbelieving Jews without Christ are as lost as unsaved Gentiles. They would suffer God's judgment and that brought great sorrow to Paul because the Gospel had come through the Jews. Think about that. The Lord Jesus, fully God and fully man but sinless, was a Jew by birth. He came to His own but His own received Him not. But we, who are non-Jews, have received by grace, salvation in Christ. How do we show our gratitude to the Lord? We pray for sinners to be convicted of their sins and turn to Christ as we proclaim the Gospel to all, including the Jews. For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek. - Romans 1:16

2 MAY.part7: For I could wish that myself were accursed from Christ for my brethren, my kinsmen according to the flesh.  THOUGHT  he apostle Paul was willing even to be counted as an enemy for Christ's sake so that his fellow unbelieving Jews might be saved. So great was his love for his brethren in the flesh that he lamented their pride and unbelief. In retrospect, Paul would have recalled the hardness of his own heart against Christ and the believers. Back then, Paul was an enemy of Christ. He was "a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious: but I obtained mercy, because I did it ignorantly in unbelief " [1 Timothy 1:13]. By God's grace, Paul was marvellously saved. Even though Paul saw himself to be the chief of sinners, he also knew God's mercy and grace were able to save even the worst of sinners. This reminds us that before we were saved by grace, we were enemies of God. We may not have murdered anyone literally but we have sinned in our hearts, minds and deeds. God's Word in Romans 5 describes us as ungodly [v. 6], sinners [v. 8] and enemies [v. 10]. There is absolutely no way we can get out of God's condemnation and holy wrath which we deserve. "But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us. Much more then, being now justified by his blood, we shall be saved from wrath through him" [Romans 5:8-9]. This wondrous truth should not only humble us to praise God for His mercies but also move us to have compassion for the unsaved. Can we hide our love and gratitude to God for His saving Grace and not share the Good News to win them to Christ? Of course not!  Brethren, my heart's desire and prayer to God for Israel is, that they might be saved. - Romans 10:1

3 MAY.part7: For I could wish that myself were accursed from Christ for my brethren, my kinsmen according to the flesh.  THOUGHT  he "for" explains what Paul said in verse 2 "that I have great heaviness and continual sorrow in my heart." He was lamenting that the Jews upon whom God had bestowed great privileges were rejecting Christ. His zeal and love for his countrymen were so strong that he was willing to be accursed in order that they might be saved. The word "accursed" is translated from the Greek word anathema, which means "destroyed". The words "I could wish" means Paul had the desire to be accursed for his brethren's sake and he wished he could. He was wishing it sincerely but knew he could not accomplish what he was wishing for. This is because theologically and doctrinally nothing was able to separate him from the love of God which is in Christ Jesus our Lord [Romans 8:38-39]. The point is that despite what his own people did, even in trying to kill him, Paul desired their salvation. No matter the cost, he was willing "to be cursed" by God for his brethren's sake so that they might know Christ. You can tell the great internal conflict Paul was struggling with. How about us? Having received so great a salvation in Christ, do we not feel like Paul, for the salvation of our loved ones? Are we not crying out to God to save our parents, siblings, and grandparents who are still idol worshippers? Indeed, we do and must. Every time we talk to them about Christ, we pray that our unsaved loved ones will respond to the Gospel and be saved. But if they remain hardened we would experience a measure of the conflict Paul went through for his fellow Jews.  While it is impossible to exchange one's soul to save another, Paul's willingness to be destroyed for the sake of Israel's salvation demonstrates the power of Christ's constraining love.

4 MAY.part7: For I could wish that myself were accursed from Christ for my brethren, my kinsmen according to the flesh.  THOUGHT  he apostle's readiness to be accursed for the sake of his unbelieving countrymen so that they might repent and turn to Christ saw a parallel in the person of Moses. While Moses was up on Mount Sinai receiving the Commandments from the Lord, the people below very quickly turned and made themselves a golden calf to worship. Exodus 32:31-32 tells us, "And Moses returned unto the LORD, and said, Oh, this people have sinned a great sin, and have made them gods of gold. Yet now, if thou wilt forgive their sin; and if not, blot me, I pray thee, out of thy book which thou hast written." Filled with righteous anger Moses confessed that the people committed a great sin by worshipping an idol. Yet despite the seriousness of their sin, Moses pleaded with the Lord for their forgiveness. If the Lord would not relent, Moses asked that he be blotted out in order that they might be spared. Moses was willing to stand in the gap between the people and God's wrath if it could avert God's just punishment. Such was Moses' love for God's people. May God give us a heart like Moses to put ourselves on the line for sinners undeserving of God's mercies. May we practise the love of Moses and Paul for God's people by looking to the example and sacrifice of One Greater, our Lord Jesus Christ, the Good Shepherd of His sheep. Only He by His Spirit will enable us to love sinners selflessly even though they are undeserving as we once were. May the love of God through us lead many to Christ.  For there is one God, and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus. - 1 Timothy 2:5

5 MAY.part3: VERSE 4 promise with Sarah, Isaac, and from Isaac's son,
5 MAY.part7: Who are Israelites; to whom pertaineth the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the service of God, and the promises.  THOUGHT  n Genesis 12, we are told that God made a covenant with Abram (later called Abraham). God had sovereignly chosen Abraham to be the one through whom a nation would be raised to be a witness for Him. They would be the descendants of Abraham. They would be given a law and a land. These three elements - people, law and land - were specific. Abraham had eight sons, but the God-chosen line was through Abraham's son of promise with Sarah, Isaac, and from Isaac's son, Jacob. In Genesis 32:28, we are further told that after his struggle with God at Peniel, Jacob's name was changed to Israel - a "prince who has prevailed with God" - to reflect his new status in God's eyes. The Israelites (also called Hebrews and later on Jews) are the people of this covenantal line, through Jacob's twelve sons. Because of a great famine, Jacob's family of seventy [Genesis 46:27] moved to Egypt under the auspices of Joseph who had become the second ruler after Pharaoh. But as time passed and pharaohs changed, the Hebrews, who were many in number, came to be perceived as a threat by the Egyptians and were enslaved. According to divine timetable, God acted and the exodus under Moses would lead His chosen people to their eventual occupation of the promised land Canaan. The number of Hebrew men above twenty years old leaving Egypt was about 600,000. Including women and children, it is estimated that the population would number about two million. God had promised to make of Abraham a great nation. Their beginnings were insignificant but against all human odds, what the Almighty God promised, He fulfilled. These were the Israelites and they were God's "special treasure". For thou art an holy people unto the LORD thy God: the LORD thy God hath chosen thee to be a special people unto himself, above all people that are upon the face of the earth. - Deuteronomy 7:6

6 MAY.part2: Advantage -- Adoption as sons and divine glory
6 MAY.part7: Who are Israelites; to whom pertaineth the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the service of God, and the promises.  THOUGHT  n abundance of privilege belongs to the Jews. To them was the privilege of being a special people chosen by God and adopted by Him as His own. To be adopted is to be conferred a status which one was not hitherto entitled. To be adopted into sonship is to inherit and become a beneficiary of all that the father owns - His blessings now and hereafter. To the Israelites was also granted the special blessing of God's "shekinah" glory manifesting His divine presence with them. In their exodus from Egypt, God's "shekinah" dwelt with them in the Ark of the Covenant within the Tabernacle. In the Promised Land, God would dwell with them in the Temple that Solomon built. But sinful as mankind were, Israel would depart from God's way and transgress His law time and time again only to be disciplined as by a loving father [Hebrews 12:6-8], and restored according to God's covenant with Abraham and His special relationship with His chosen people. Fast forward to the time of Paul and to our day, the promised Son of David has come and the way of salvation to Gentiles is open through the Gospel of Jesus Christ. Gentiles who put their faith in Jesus as their Lord and Saviour, now enjoy adoption into God's family as the Israelites were, and become spiritual children of Abraham [Galatians 3:26-29]. God's presence and glory will dwell with them, not in a tent or temple built with hands, but by the Holy Spirit in their hearts, and they are called by Christ's name. It now behoves the Christian to show forth the glory of God, as a witness and light to the world. Know ye not that ye are the temple of God, and that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you? - 1 Corinthians 3:16

7 MAY.part3: VERSE 4 and his posterity of an eternal kingdom through a
7 MAY.part7: Who are Israelites; to whom pertaineth the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the service of God, and the promises.  THOUGHT  nother privilege pertaining to the Israelites as God's chosen people was the covenants He made with them. The Abrahamic covenant singled them out as God's elect and promised them a land. The Mosaic covenant initiated and developed their growth as a nation. They were given a codified law to order their lives for their benefit. They would learn the consequences of faithlessness and the blessings of faithfulness. The Davidic covenant would establish God's promise to Israel's king and his posterity of an eternal kingdom through a promised future Son of his line. The Law given at Sinai was the sign of God's divine rule over them. It covered all aspects of Israelite life - moral, civil and ceremonial. Obedience would result in His approval and blessing. Disobedience would incur His displeasure and chastisement. The Law was for their good. God was the originator of all His covenants. Only He could fulfil them. Other than the Mosaic covenant which required Israel's compliance, these were "unconditional" covenants because God made them, and He alone would keep His promises. Christians today are the beneficiaries of these covenants because what God gave to the Jews at the outset, He has given to us because of their rejection of His Son [Romans 11:11]. Our lives are ordered by God's moral Law. We are saved because He sent His Son in fulfilment of His covenant with David, which leads to His establishment of the New Covenant whereby His Law is written in our hearts, and every person, Jew or Gentile, who calls upon Jesus the Saviour in faith for forgiveness, will receive His saving grace and eternal life. The New Covenant: "But this shall be the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel; After those days, saith the LORD, I will put my law in their inward parts, and write it in their hearts; and will be their God, and they shall be my people." [Jeremiah 31:33]

8 MAY.part7: Who are Israelites; to whom pertaineth the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the service of God, and the promises.  THOUGHT  o the Israelites were also given the privilege of service. Service is divine worship. This was encapsulated in the whole body of the moral, ceremonial and civil Law which necessitated reverential obedience and execution. This Law originated from God, and it would differentiate them from the idol-worshipping nations around them. Worship carried out correctly would give reverence to God who set His love upon them and chose them not because they were great or righteous. Worshipping in obedience would glorify the Giver. The Israelites were given the singular honour of being the people by which God's great salvation plan for mankind would unfold. The promise to Abraham of being the father of many nations centred around the Hebrew people. The greatest promise of the coming Jewish Messiah, who would bring eternal life and usher in an eternal kingdom, would be fulfilled through the line of David of the tribe of Judah [Revelation 5:5]. Jerusalem, the city in the land promised according to God's covenant with the Israelites, will be the centre of God's dominion on earth in the future millennial kingdom. Christians today have the privilege of service and the benefits of God's promises. We are saved by faith in the risen Son of David. Our worship and service reflect our love and desire to obey Him. We worship not in lip-service, external rituals and merit-seeking gestures but by submission to Him in obedience. To obey is greater than sacrifice [1 Samuel 15:22]. And we look forward to the eternal kingdom promised and reserved for us. God wants our lives, not our words. "I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service" [Romans 12:1].

9 MAY.part3: VERSE 5 But Paul saves the most exalted privilege of all to
9 MAY.part7: Whose are the fathers, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever. Amen.  THOUGHT  he pain Paul feels for his lost brethren is all the more severe when he considers how God has blessed them with all the privileges of being His own special people. In verse 4, Paul listed several of those privileges, and here in verse 5, he continues. "Whose are the fathers" refer to the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac and Jacob whom the Jews are so privileged to have as their ancestors, and to whom the promises of God to mankind had been given. But Paul saves the most exalted privilege of all to the last; "and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came". Christ, the Messiah, the Saviour of mankind would be born to the nation of Israel, in particular, the tribe of Judah. In many ways, Christians have privileges similar to those of the Jews, especially those of us who are born into Christian families. From young, we are brought to church, taught the Scriptures there and at home, and sheltered in many ways from the evil influences of the world. Some even attend Christian schools where they receive sound Christian education. What should our response be? Firstly, we should be grateful and bless the Lord with our whole being and never forget all the multiplied benefits of His grace and goodness [Psalm 103:2]. Like Paul, we should say "God (be) blessed for ever. Amen." Secondly, we should use our resources to serve the Lord and go where He sends us. God forbid that we should use all that He has blessed us with for our own enjoyment and to satisfy our worldly lusts.  All the Lord's people should be employed in the Lord's vineyard for the Lord's glory. - James Smith, Daily Remembrancer

10 MAY.part7: Whose are the fathers, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever. Amen.  THOUGHT  he third chapter of Matthew's Gospel documents an encounter between John the Baptist and a group of Pharisees and Sadducees who had come to him for baptism. He warned them not to presume that just because they were the descendants of Abraham, they could "flee from the wrath to come" [Matthew 3:7], that they would automatically qualify for citizenship in the Messiah's kingdom. Many of the Jews, including those of our day, believe that circumcision plus perhaps the confession of the creed of Israel "the LORD our God is one LORD" [Deuteronomy 6:4], would be enough to ensure their admission into the "bosom" of Abraham because Abraham's righteousness would be reckoned as theirs. John told them that they needed to "bring forth therefore fruits meet for repentance" [Matthew 3:8]. Indeed, many Christians have the same erroneous concept of salvation. They think that because they were born to godly parents, baptized as infants and grew up in Christian homes, they are saved. The Bible, especially in the Book of Romans, clearly teaches that this is not so. Only those who truly repent of their sins and receive Jesus Christ as their Lord and Saviour are saved. May the Lord grant us the burden and opportunities to bring the true Gospel of salvation to our unsaved friends and loved ones. Pray that He will give us the courage to point out this error among our Christian friends who have this wrong idea or have been taught some other false doctrines.  Enter ye in at the strait gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way, that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in thereat. - Matthew 7:13

11 MAY.part3: VERSE 5 concerning the flesh Christ came. God, who ts over
11 MAY.part7: Whose are the fathers, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever. Amen.  THOUGHT  n verse 5, Paul adds an important detail about Jesus Christ; that He is "over all". Albert Barnes, commented that, "This is an appellation that belongs only to the true God. It implies supreme divinity; and is full proof that the Messiah is divine." Still there are others who argue and deny the deity of Christ, saying that we ought to place a period after the words "concerning the flesh Christ came," thus causing the verse to read: "...as concerning the flesh Christ came. God, who is over all, be blessed for ever. Amen." The argument is rejected for two reasons. Firstly, Paul, in this section of the Epistle of Romans, is emphasizing that his countrymen "have a zeal of God, but not according to knowledge" [Romans 10:2]. The man they had crucified for being so audacious in claiming to be God, is in fact "the very God". This is consistent with what Paul teaches in many of his epistles; for example, in Philippians 2:10-11, "that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow ... And that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father." Secondly, the deity of Christ is taught in many other parts of the Bible. For example, in Matthew 1, the angel Gabriel informed Joseph that the birth of his son was a fulfilment of Old Testament prophecy, and "they shall call his name Emmanuel, which being interpreted is, God with us" [Matthew 1:23]. Likewise, the Gospel of John is basically about the deity of Christ. Thus, we can confidently pronounce, Jesus Christ, "Who is over all, God blessed for ever. Amen." In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. - John 1:1

12 MAY.part3: VERSE 5 with the teachings of the Scriptures.
12 MAY.part7: Whose are the fathers, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever. Amen.  THOUGHT  ld Testament prophecies of the Messiah often hint of His dual nature. A good example is Isaiah 9:6 which we often quote at Christmas; "Unto us a child is born" speaks of the human nature of this man who would be born to human parents. "Unto us a son is given" attests to His identity as the Son of God proclaimed in another well-known Bible verse: John 3:16. Hence what Paul states here in Romans 9:5 is entirely consistent with the teachings of the Scriptures. The mystery of the human-divine nature of Christ is beyond our finite understanding, but it is central to our Christian faith. It also holds the key to our salvation. The Son of God had to take on human form in order to be able to die for our sins. As a man, He was subject to His parents in His youth, engaged in the carpenter's trade, ate and slept like other men and was subject to suffering and finally death, like all others. As a man, He was "in all points tempted like as we are, yet without sin." [Hebrews 4:15]. What sets Jesus Christ apart from all the other religious leaders of the world is that He is, in the words of the Westminster Confession of Faith, "very God, and very man, yet one Christ, the only Mediator between God and man"; which means that "Neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved." [Acts 4:12].  Do not be ashamed of the Gospel of Christ; "For it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth" [Roman 1:16].

13 MAY.part3: VERSE 6 but only in those whose hearts are touched by
13 MAY.part7: Not as though the word of God hath taken none effect. For they are not all Israel, which are of Israel.  THOUGHT  od had promised Abraham "And I will establish my covenant between me and thee and thy seed after thee in their generations for an everlasting covenant, to be a God unto thee, and to thy seed after thee" [Genesis 17:7]. This promise was to Israel and yet Israel rejected God. However, this did not abrogate God's promise. Paul explains that God's promise was not meant to be fulfilled in ALL the descendants of Abraham but only in those whose hearts are touched by His grace, who rest their trust in Him and seek to obey His will. These are the "spiritual children" of Abraham who constitute "spiritual Israel". Conversely those who reject (disbelieve) God and His Son are not and belong to "natural Israel". The lineage of Abraham, external ceremonies and circumcision do not gain salvation. It requires the circumcision of the heart, which corresponds to an inward transformation [Romans 2:28-29]. "Natural Israel", which is the vast majority, rebelled against God and His appointed servants. They rebelled against Moses and were slain by God in the wilderness. They killed the prophets God sent to warn them. Except for a faithful remnant, the nation as a whole became apostate and deserving of God's judgment. The Northern Kingdom was overthrown by the Assyrians in 722 BC and the Southern Kingdom destroyed by Babylonians in 586 BC. When our Lord Jesus, God Incarnate, went to them, the nation had little faith. They rejected His teachings and denied their promised Messiah. In their cruel hatred, they crucified Him. Blinded by Satan, "natural Israel" put to death their Saviour whom God had promised their father Abraham. Sadly, today, secular Israel is "natural Israel". To day if ye will hear his voice, Harden not your heart, as in the provocation, and as in the day of temptation in the wilderness: When your fathers tempted me, proved me, and saw my work. - Psalm 95:7b-9

14 MAY.part3: VERSE 6 God, accepting that He died a substitutionary death
14 MAY.part7: Not as though the word of God hath taken none effect. For they are not all Israel, which are of Israel.  THOUGHT  hat is required to be a "true" or "spiritual Israelite"? The great majority of Jews, led by their religious leaders, mistakenly believed that receiving the Law, the promises of God, temple worship, ceremonies and circumcision would automatically make them God's children. But those divine privileges and advantages in themselves did not bring salvation. Paul's answer is that only believing faith in Jesus of Nazareth, the Son of God, accepting that He died a substitutionary death for our sins and imputed His righteousness upon us will save [2 Corinthians 5:21]. The "spiritual Israel" of the Old Testament believed God and His promises, and looked forward to the coming of the promised Messiah in Christ Jesus whom they had neither seen nor knew [Hebrews 11:1]. Abraham was an example of such faith [Romans 4]. He was declared righteous by God [Genesis 15:6] even before he was circumcised [Genesis 17] and before the giving of the Law to Moses, which was 400 years later [Exodus 16]. Even so, Abraham would not have been able to keep the Law for it would only condemn the lawbreaker and bring upon him God's wrath. It was Abraham's faith in God that made him a "spiritual Israelite". Abraham is the spiritual father to all who, like him, are called and in faith believe in God "who quickeneth the dead, and calleth those things which be not as though they were" [Romans 4:16-17]. God honours people of such faith throughout the history of "spiritual Israel" [Hebrews 11]. The "spiritual Israel" of the New Testament looks back in time, believing on the Saviour Jesus Christ, His finished work of salvation on Calvary's cross for repentant sinners and looking forward to His glorious return soon. But as many as received Him, to them gave He power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on His name. - John 1:12

15 MAY.part3: VERSE 6 Ancient Antioch was known for its immorality.
15 MAY.part7: Not as though the word of God hath taken none effect. For they are not all Israel, which are of Israel.  THOUGHT  ust as many Jews think they are true sons of Abraham when they are not, many people think they are Christians when they are not. They may attend church worship regularly, read the Bible, pray, sing hymns and participate actively in church activities, but external Christian activities do not validate one as a true Christian. If their hearts remain untouched by the Gospel and their lives unchanged, they are merely "cultural Christians". Ancient Antioch was known for its immorality. God raised a group of genuine believers who were so enamoured by Christ they followed Him closely, manifested His teachings and character. The pagans called them Christ's ones or "Christians" because they were distinct from others in their society. Genuine Christians are those whose hearts have been touched by the Gospel, convicted by the Holy Spirit and ... 1. Believe and have faith in Jesus Christ, the Son of God Incarnate as their Lord and Saviour. 2. Whose hearts are regenerated so as to be a new creature in Christ [2 Corinthians 5:17]. 3. Are committed to follow Jesus Christ in obedience [John 10:27], striving to be like Him. 4. Have a compassion for souls, ready to witness for Christ so that others may be saved [Acts 1:8]. 5. Desire to know Jesus, to be more like Him by drawing close to Him daily, knowing His Word, praying and doing His will [Philippians 3:10]. "Cultural Christians" do not bear these marks of true Christianity. Cultural Christianity comes about from wrong doctrine, adopting the easy-believism mindset, hardened hearts, complacency and the deception of the devil. But the faithful preaching of God's pure Word with the conviction of hearts produces genuine saving faith. For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek. - Romans 1:16

16 MAY.part3: VERSE 6 who He is and what He has done for my salvation?
16 MAY.part7: Not as though the word of God hath taken none effect. For they are not all Israel, which are of Israel.  THOUGHT  n His earthly ministry, the Lord Jesus had forewarned those around Him that "Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven ... I never knew you: depart from me, ye that work iniquity" [Matthew 7:21-23]. It behoves us to examine ourselves if we are truly His with these questions. Do I have true faith believing the Lord Jesus, who He is and what He has done for my salvation? Sin has condemned all men to eternal death [Romans 3:23]. Man is unable to save himself. By the mercies and grace of God, His Son came, died on our behalf to take away our sins and rose again to give us everlasting life [Romans 6:23]. Am I following Christ? When called by Him to "follow Me," His disciples committed their all to Him with transformed hearts and redirected lives. Have I been reborn as a new creature? Has my life and character changed? Have I turned away from past sins and now hunger after righteousness and spiritual things with eternal values in view [Colossians 3:1-17]? Do I manifest the fruit of the spirit [Galatians 5:22-23] in my life? Do I testify for Christ? In deep gratitude for having received such great salvation, do I have compassion for the souls of others to win them for my Saviour as commanded in His Great Commission [Matthew 28:18-20]? Am I drawing closer to my Lord Jesus through the study of His Word and communion with Him in prayer? Do I diligently seek His will and live in total obedience to Him [Philippians 3:10]? I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service. And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God. - Romans 12:1-2

17 MAY.part3: VERSE 7 sons, only Isaac, the son born to Sarah in her
17 MAY.part7: Neither, because they are the seed of Abraham, are they all children: but, In Isaac shall thy seed be called.  THOUGHT  postle Paul explained to the Christians in Rome that Jews could not become a member of God's family simply because they were the biological offspring of Abraham. He illustrated this through the examples of the patriarchs, beginning with Abraham and his son, Isaac. Firstly, God chose Abraham while he was living in idolatry in Ur of the Chaldees and Abraham in complete faith obeyed God's call. Of Abraham's sons, only Isaac, the son born to Sarah in her old age, and his seed would be blessed through God's covenant with Abraham [Genesis 17:19, 21]. Isaac was the only son born out of a promise given by God, through supernatural means to a father and mother too advanced in age to have children naturally. Neither Ishmael, born of Sarah's Egyptian handmaid Hagar, nor any of the six sons Abraham had with his concubine Keturah were part of this blessed line [Genesis 25:1-2]. Although they were the seed of Abraham, they were not the spiritual seed God had promised him. We were chosen by God even while we were living in sin, with nothing good in us to merit salvation. We were spiritually reborn by divine means when it seemed hopeless and impossible for our hearts to be regenerated. Our election and salvation cannot be justified and explained by human logic and reasoning. God brought us into His fold and saved us from our sin because of His love for us. Thank God for His marvellous grace and bounteous mercy that drew us to Him with cords of love.  No man can come to me, except the Father which hath sent me draw him: and I will raise him up at the last day. - John 6:44

18 MAY.part3: VERSE 7 of God's preservation and blessing, God even
18 MAY.part7: Neither, because they are the seed of Abraham, are they all children: but, In Isaac shall thy seed be called.  THOUGHT  ome may reason that Isaac was chosen by God because he had the "right" parentage while Ishmael was not a pure-blooded Jew. The Apostle Paul debunks this misconception with the example of Jacob and Esau, the twin sons of Isaac and his wife, Rebekah. Scripture tells us that only Jacob was chosen by God even before the boys' birth [Genesis 25:23]. The events in Jacob's life bore evidence of God's preservation and blessing. God even changed Jacob's name to Israel and promised him great blessings [Genesis 35:10-12]. Indeed the 12 tribes of Israel were the offspring of his sons and grandsons. The priestly line originated from Levi, while the prophets sent by God to preach repentance to Israel and the surrounding nations came from the twelve tribes. Our Lord Jesus, the Promised Messiah, was from the tribe of Judah. These are all assurances that the seed of Jacob was the children promised by God. God's election of the patriarchs, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, demonstrates that He elects whom He wills to be His holy seed. They responded in faith and received salvation. The Jews failed to understand the true meaning of God's promises to them. They took pride in being Abraham's seed, thinking they were the children of God but rejected the Messiah sent from God. Jesus identified them as children of the devil [John 8:44] for refusing to believe the Gospel message He brought them. This is a solemn warning to all. If we reject Jesus as our Saviour who takes away our sin, God will not recognize us as His. Jesus said unto them, If God were your Father, ye would love me: for I proceeded forth and came from God; neither came I of myself, but he sent me. - John 8:42

19 MAY.part7: That is, They which are the children of the flesh, these are not the children of God: but the children of the promise are counted for the seed.  THOUGHT  hile God chose Israel to play a very important role in His redemptive plan, God has not chosen one race or nation alone to be saved, to the exclusion of others. The Jews boasted of being Abraham's children, but Jesus told them plainly that mere physical descent did not make one a child of God [John 8:32-40]. They were Abraham's physical descendants but did not display the same saving faith as Abraham. Their denial of Jesus as the Son of God and rejection of the salvation He offered meant they remained servants of sin. Paul emphasizes that there is a distinction between the physical nation of Israel and the spiritual people of God. Salvation comes upon the chosen spiritual children of God. They hear the Gospel, respond in faith believing that the Lord Jesus will cleanse them of their sins, and give their lives to obey Him. The vast majority of Jews past and present do not believe that Jesus is the Messiah sent from God to save mankind despite the religious education they have since childhood. In the early church and even till today, new Christian converts are overwhelmingly Gentiles. Dear reader, do you believe God's promise to save us through His only begotten Son, Jesus Christ? Let us not be deceived into thinking that our birth into a Christian family, our attendance in church or Sunday School will earn us any spiritual privileges. Every one of us is individually accountable to God and must demonstrate personal faith. We will not be saved if we harbour unbelief and refuse to place our faith in the Saviour.  Israel had the advantage of knowing God's laws, yet many did not believe. We have the advantage of reading the complete Bible, do you believe it?

20 MAY.part7: That is, They which are the children of the flesh, these are not the children of God: but the children of the promise are counted for the seed.  THOUGHT  he children of promise are chosen by God to be His blood-bought children. God's sovereign grace elected them to believe and have faith in the promises of His Word. God promised in His Word to save us from our sins through the sacrifice of His only begotten Son Jesus Christ. The Old Testament patriarchs and believers believed this promise of God. They looked forward to the coming of the Messiah who would take away sin. Their faith and belief saved them, even though they never lived to see Jesus. We, who live after the time of Christ, look back at His death and resurrection. We praise God that the prophecies concerning the Messiah have been fulfilled. We trust that God the Father has accepted the sacrifice of His Son to atone for our sins, so we have the blessed hope of eternal life. The Holy Spirit transforms us, and we live in obedience to Him now. We love God and seek to glorify Him because He first loved us. Our lives display works that are evidence of our faith. We love others and gladly witness the Gospel to them. All these characterize the children of promise. The children of the flesh are the opposite of the children of promise. They do not have faith in God and His promises. Alas, they do not believe the message of salvation and remain lost in sin. We thank God for His sovereign grace, mercy, and love for us in electing us to be His children.  For we are the circumcision, which worship God in the spirit, and rejoice in Christ Jesus, and have no confidence in the flesh. - Philippians 3:3

21 MAY.part3: VERSE 9 bless him and Sarah in His appointed time [Genesis
21 MAY.part7: For this is the word of promise, At this time will I come, and Sarah shall have a son.  THOUGHT  od gave His word of promise that Abraham would have a child by Sarah [Genesis 18:10]. God was clear that this chosen one by whom He would bless all the people of the earth [Genesis 12:3; 17:9] would be through Sarah and not Hagar. The promise made to Abraham and Sarah seemed humanly impossible for they were old, and Sarah had been barren for many years. Yet God repeatedly declared to Abraham that He would bless him and Sarah in His appointed time [Genesis 18:14]. This was fulfilled in the conception and birth of Isaac. The strength of a promise and the likelihood of it being fulfilled depends entirely on the person making the promise. If the person is trustworthy, he will be sincere and intend to fulfil his promise. However, if he is sincere but powerless, the promise is still empty. Likewise, if a person is deceitful and cannot be trusted, even though he may be powerful, the promise made will be unfulfilled as well. Jehovah, the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob as He has revealed Himself to us through His Holy Word, is the one true and living God who is faithful to His promises, sovereign and omnipotent. He is true for He cannot lie, and He is able to fulfil all He says He will do. Praise God! He keeps the promises He makes to us! "God is not a man, that he should lie; neither the son of man, that he should repent: hath he said, and shall he not do it? or hath he spoken, and shall he not make it good?" [Numbers 23:19]. "God is faithful, by whom ye were called unto the fellowship of his Son Jesus Christ our Lord." [1 Corinthians 1:9]. For all the promises of God in him are yea, and in him Amen, unto the glory of God by us. - 2 Corinthians 1:20

22 MAY.part7: For the children being not yet born, neither having done any good or evil, that the purpose of God according to election might stand, not of works, but of Him that calleth.  THOUGHT  he Word of God further shows how God chooses in His sovereign wisdom and will. God in His time caused Sarah to conceive by Abraham so that the covenant people would be by the line of Isaac. Then Rebekah conceived twins by Isaac. God declared to the parents that Rebekah was bearing twins and the pattern of their relations as ordained by God. "And the LORD said unto her, Two nations are in thy womb, and two manner of people shall be separated from thy bowels; and the one people shall be stronger than the other people; and the elder shall serve the younger" [Genesis 25:23]. Jacob's line was chosen to be the heirs of election despite his being the younger. This election was by God's grace, and God's sovereign will determines their relationship. Although the two sons sinned in their actions growing up, God is not the author of evil. "Let no man say when he is tempted, I am tempted of God: for God cannot be tempted with evil, neither tempteth he any man" [James 1:13]. The illustration from redemptive history serves to illustrate God's election. All mankind are sinners and morally corrupt after Adam fell. In this state of depravity, none understands nor seeks after God [Romans 3:10-11]. The only reason a person believes in His Son, Jesus Christ is that they are elected by God to be saved. This election to be saved is of His sovereign grace. Without this election, sinners are passed over and left in their depraved state destined for reprobation and death. "Turn us again, O God, and cause thy face to shine; and we shall be saved." [Psalm 80:3] But the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit of God: for they are foolishness unto him: neither can he know them, because they are spiritually discerned. - 1 Corinthians 2:14

23 MAY.part3: VERSE 11 for being elected to salvation! Mankind's best works
23 MAY.part7: For the children being not yet born, neither having done any good or evil, that the purpose of God according to election might stand, not of works, but of Him that calleth.  THOUGHT  he twins Jacob and Esau were elected to their paths ordained by God not because of anything they had done. At the time of God's announcing His plans, they were as yet unborn. They had not committed any acts themselves. The grounds of election by God are "of Him that calleth". They are found in God alone. It is not of any human merit. In fact, before the Almighty, Holy and Triune God, no man can lay claim to their works or worthiness for being elected to salvation! Mankind's best works are but worthy of condemnation. "But we are all as an unclean thing, and all our righteousnesses are as filthy rags; and we all do fade as a leaf; and our iniquities, like the wind, have taken us away" [Isaiah 64:6]. Therefore, the grounds for election are not to be found in the creature. The conditions for election are not in man. They are found in God the Creator's will and pleasure. Thus, election is termed to be unconditional because it is not based on anything in the elected person that warrants it. This doctrine has been termed "Unconditional Election" and is based on God's Word alone. This election is God's sovereign election, and He imparts grace, in electing those whom He would save. This runs totally contrary to any man's ideas that he has chosen God. "Ye have not chosen me, but I have chosen you, and ordained you, that ye should go and bring forth fruit, and that your fruit should remain: that whatsoever ye shall ask of the Father in my name, He may give it you." [John 15:16]  Who hath saved us, and called us with an holy calling, not according to our works, but according to His own purpose and grace, which was given us in Christ Jesus before the world began. - 2 Timothy 1:9

24 MAY.part2: The Purpose of God in Election
24 MAY.part7: For the children being not yet born, neither having done any good or evil, that the purpose of God according to election might stand, not of works, but of Him that calleth.  THOUGHT  od's purpose in election is to work out His plan of redemption for His chosen ones among sinful mankind. This plan is all God's doing and of His will and pleasure. God chose Jacob to be the line from which His covenant people and the Messiah, Jesus Christ would come, whilst Jacob was yet unborn. He had no works to deserve any action of God towards him. God's Word is clear that in doing so, election's purpose shows that it is God who calls and not mankind who initiates the plan. Jehovah is the great I AM, the self-existent without whom nothing and nobody would exist and be. The Universe was created by God from nothing. He created physical life where there was nothing. He gives spiritual life where there is only death. He initiates this by election in and of Himself, and no one else. God works all things for His own glory and pleasure. We are elected to salvation for this. "Declaring the end from the beginning, and from ancient times the things that are not yet done, saying, My counsel shall stand, and I will do all my pleasure" [Isaiah 46:10]. "But God hath chosen the foolish things of the world to confound the wise; and God hath chosen the weak things of the world to confound the things which are mighty; and base things of the world, and things which are despised, hath God chosen, yea, and things which are not, to bring to nought things that are: that no flesh should glory in his presence." [1 Corinthians 1:2729]  Having made known unto us the mystery of His will, according to His good pleasure which He hath purposed in Himself ... That we should be to the praise of His glory, who first trusted in Christ. - Ephesians 1:9, 12

25 MAY.part7: As it is written, Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated.  THOUGHT  hat does Paul mean by asserting that God "loved" Jacob but "hated" Esau? Some understand Paul to mean only that God loved Esau less than He loved Jacob; God blessed both, but Jacob was used in a more positive and basic way in the furtherance of God's plans. However, a better approach is to define "hatred" here by its opposite, "love". If God's love of Jacob consists in His choosing Jacob to be the seed who would inherit the blessings promised to Abraham, then God's hatred of Esau is best understood to refer to God's decision not to bestow this privilege on Esau. It might be better rendered "reject". Here, "love" and "hate" are not emotions that God feels but actions that He carries out. God's action is to bestow His salvation on those He chooses, which is the traditional Calvinistic interpretation of God's election. The issue which troubles many is how God, who is described as a God of love, can withhold His love in action, or election from some, and hate (reject) them. They should rather be asking themselves why God should love them in the first place. In the many generations following Jacob, it was revealed to the Israelites that God's choice to bestow His love upon them was not due to anything found in them, not on the grounds of some intrinsic goodness, some greater intelligence, some moral superiority, or some military prowess, but solely in the love found in God Himself.  The LORD did not set His love upon you, nor choose you, because ye were more in number than any people; for ye were the fewest of all people: But because the LORD loved you. - Deuteronomy 7:7-8a

26 MAY.part7: As it is written, Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated.  THOUGHT  od's election of Jacob to be the recipient of the seed which would inherit the blessings promised to Abraham did not originate in Jacob. Neither did God compare Jacob to Esau and determined that Jacob had greater potential to do good. The choice had nothing to do with the actual good or the potential good, the actual or potential evil, of Jacob and Esau. Neither did God look down the corridors of time to see whether Jacob or Esau would respond in faith and therefore chose one. This false teaching is the Arminian position where faith becomes the basis for God's choice. Election has to do with the purpose of God. It is of His sovereign good pleasure. Election is intertwined with the sovereignty of God. In a broad sense, God decides to do whatever He desires, without pressure or constraint from any outside influence. And ever since the creation, God has sovereignly prescribed or permitted everything in human history, in order that He might accomplish the redemptive plan which He had previously designed to "accomplish that which (He) please(s)" [Isaiah 55:11]. God chooses whomever He chooses, for reasons that are wholly His. This is evident in John 15:16 where Jesus told His disciples, "Ye have not chosen me, but I have chosen you, and ordained you". In 1 Timothy 5:21 this is reflected in God's choice of his "elect angels". And this again demonstrates that God has "chosen us in Him (Jesus) before the foundation of the world" [Ephesians 1:4].  God does not choose us because we believe, but that we may believe. - Augustine

27 MAY.part7: As it is written, Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated.  THOUGHT  nce again, God did not look in the future to see whether Esau would reject God's call to faith and then to act upon that knowledge. God's election of Jacob for eternal salvation and the passing over of Esau originate from His eternal counsels, the latter of which is called reprobation. Although both election and reprobation follow from the will of God, there is a difference between the two. In election, God regenerates the heart, and this precedes faith. More precisely, regeneration is the cause of faith. In the doctrine of reprobation, those who are lost are not made to disbelief by God. Rather, God chooses to withhold the grace of regeneration. The heart of stone remains as stone in such an unbeliever and as a result, the reprobate does not come to faith of his own accord. And since such a one is still burdened by the punishment for sin as they do not have their sins forgiven, God judges them according to the strict standards of divine justice. This is most clearly evident in the hardening of Pharoah's heart in Exodus. First references are to God's hardening of Pharaoh's heart. God has eternally decreed to refrain from extending saving grace to Pharaoh. This is then followed by Pharaoh's own self-hardening. Without a renewed heart, there will be deliberate disobedience to God's will. Even in the doctrine of reprobation, God demonstrates that He is absolutely sovereign. Even the reprobate is subject to Him.  Therefore hath he mercy on whom he will have mercy, and whom he will he hardeneth. - Romans 9:18

28 MAY.part7: As it is written, Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated.  THOUGHT  he answer to the first question of the Westminster Shorter Catechism tells us that "Man's chief end is to glorify God, and to enjoy Him forever." It should be noted that all men, elect and reprobate, glorify God. In the doctrine of election, the glory of His free love and bountiful grace bestowed upon God's elect is on full display at the cross. In the doctrine of reprobation, the passing over of some to dishonour and wrath for their sin displays the glory of God's justice and righteousness. And when these two doctrines are considered side by side, where all men do not deserve His salvation grace but rather deserve eternal condemnation, the doctrine of reprobation magnifies the divine mercy and love of God. These two doctrines demonstrate that God's absolute rule and control is maintained and cannot be overturned or overcome by man's will or circumstances. By extension, this implies that whatever God has decreed before the foundation of the world will come to pass. We can have great confidence that those whom God did predestinate are those whom He called; and those that He called will be justified and thereafter glorified [Romans 8:30]. God does not begin a work He does not finish. May we trust in God's promise that "if we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins" [1 John 1:9]. Let us reflect upon the words in this familiar hymn: Amazing grace how sweet the sound That saved a wretch like me. I once was lost, but now I'm found, Was blind but now I see. (John Newton) But by the grace of God I am what I am: and his grace which was bestowed upon me was not in vain; but I laboured more abundantly than they all: yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me. - 1 Corinthians 15:10

29 MAY.part7: What shall we say then? Is there unrighteousness with God? God forbid.  THOUGHT  It is not fair" is a common complaint. The implication is that all we want is fairness. We want to treat others fairly, and in return, we want to be treated fairly. And we also want God to be fair to us! In Romans 9:14, Paul is anticipating what he knew many would ask about his words in the preceding verse; that God loved Jacob and hated Esau. Does God's favour upon Jacob and not Esau mean that God was unrighteous? Paul's answer was an emphatic no. "God forbid" literally means "May it never be!" The exclamatory phrase suggests that Paul regards the question as outrageous. By virtue of who He is, God cannot possibly be unjust [Genesis 18:25]. John Calvin writes: "Monstrous surely is the madness of the human mind, that it is more disposed to charge God with unrighteousness than to blame (himself) for blindness." Another commentator points out that if God were to save all on account of who they are and what they have done - faith, good works - that would also be inherently unfair because their backgrounds and upbringing are not equal. Some owing to their natural temperament or their being raised in a believing family, may find it easier to be more trusting. For the same reasons, it is easier for some to be good and moral people. Others, being raised in violent, immoral or heathen backgrounds, would be more inclined to sin and rebellion. Hence, if God's election is based on a sinner's deeds, that would be unfair. The greatest act of injustice is Christ dying for our sins "the just for the unjust, that he might bring us to God" [1 Peter 3:18]. Good and upright is the LORD: therefore will He teach sinners in the way. - Psalm 25:8

30 MAY.part7: What shall we say then? Is there unrighteousness with God? God forbid.  THOUGHT  he question in verse 14 suggests that sinners have rights, and that God has violated those rights. The question is: can we legitimately claim God has violated our rights? The answer is again an emphatic no. We have sinned against God. We have trampled on the Almighty and His holy law. Fairness and justice would mean that He must give us what we deserve - death. "The soul that sinneth, it shall die" [Ezekiel 18:4, 20]. "The wages of sin is death" [Romans 6:23]. To get what we deserve is perfect justice, and we have no grounds to accuse God of being unjust if He does not grant us mercy and salvation. Christ illustrates this truth in a parable in Matthew 20:1-16. A landowner went into the marketplace in the morning and hired workers for his vineyard. The agreed wage was one penny for the day's work. At different times of the day, the landowner returned and hired more workers, agreeing to pay them whatever was right. At the end of the day, the landowner paid the earliest group one penny. The workers who worked for just an hour were also paid one penny. That sparked cries of unfairness from those who had worked the whole day. The landowner said to them, "Didst not thou agree with me for a penny? ... Is it not lawful for me to do what I will with mine own? Is thine eye evil, because I am good?" [Matthew 20:13-15]. The landowner was fair when he gave the first group of workers what they had agreed. He was gracious to the last group. All sinners deserve God's wrath. There is no unfairness on God's part. The elect receive God's grace, which is His to dispense. For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God; Being justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus. - Romans 3:23-24

31 MAY.part7: For he saith to Moses, I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion.  THOUGHT  s election fair? This is a good question - if it is not just for theoretical debate. Many have asked this with genuine desire to know who God is. Firstly, we should realise that fairness is not a matter of God's mercy, but rather a question about His justice. Is it just for God to show mercy to some, and not to others? The answer is - if God was to be just according to His holy standard, then all of us are bound for destruction and hell. Yet God has chosen some to be saved despite who we are, for reasons He has not revealed to anyone. Why did God save some, and pass by others? It is certainly not a matter of merit. Those whom God regenerates might be the worst of sinners, yet when God's grace comes upon them, it is irresistible. The truth is God does not owe us an answer. Romans 9:15 tells us clearly that He the sovereign God who creates, also determines. Those whom God saved despite their sinfulness ought to be grateful for His mercies, and seek to extend the good news of salvation to others, so that they can also enjoy His saving grace. How does knowing this help us understand God's attributes then? Both His justice and His mercy tell of His glory. God, in punishing sinners, displays His power, omniscience and justice. Yet by His sovereign prerogative and determination, He has given sinful humankind the way of escape, which in turn demonstrates His love and grace. Through both reprobation of sinners and election of the saved, God's name is glorified.  For the earth shall be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the LORD, as the waters cover the sea. - Habakkuk 2:14

1 JUNE.part7: For he saith to Moses, I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion.  THOUGHT  e often use "mercy" and "grace" interchangeably, because these two gifts of God are closely inter-related. If we were to think more deeply, the difference between these two words will offer much insight on our condition and God's love for us. To the believer, "mercy" tells about the despairing situation we were once in. We were once condemned and destined for hell, but God had mercy and pardoned our transgressions by taking on the punishment upon Himself. "Grace", on the other hand, is God bestowing upon us the merits we do not deserve. God has absolutely no obligation to bestow upon us His righteousness and blessings, yet He has out of the abundance of His grace. In short, "mercy" is God withholding from us the punishment and judgment that we deserve, and "grace" is God bestowing upon us the gifts and blessings that we do not deserve. To the non-believer, God's mercies and grace are also apparent and new every morning. It is by His mercies that this sinful world still stands, and that sinners are not consumed by His anger against sin. Instead, God added His grace upon His mercy by sustaining the world (in theological terms called common grace) and extending the offer of salvation (saving grace) to anyone who will believe. "The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance" [2 Peter 3:9]. Believers or not, let us not take God's mercies for granted. Neither should we frustrate His grace toward us. Come, know the Lord. Then thank Him for His mercy and cherish every day to sing of His goodness. Praise God for His grace and use every moment to be a channel of blessing to others. I will sing of the mercies of the LORD for ever: with my mouth will I make known thy faithfulness to all generations. - Psalm 89:1
part8: THOUGHT I will sing of the mercies of the LORD for ever:

2 JUNE.part3: VERSE 15 will shew mercy.' God was merciful and gracious
2 JUNE.part7: For he saith to Moses, I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion.  THOUGHT  omans 9:15 found its Old Testament roots in Exodus 33:19. It was shortly after the golden calf incident and Moses was very discouraged. He wanted assurance from God that He would be with them [Exodus 33:15], even asking God to show him His glory [Exodus 33:18]. To this request, God had answered, "I will make all My goodness pass before thee, and I will proclaim the name of the LORD before thee; and will be gracious to whom I will be gracious, and will shew mercy on whom I will shew mercy." God was merciful and gracious towards Moses not because Moses was good in his own righteousness, but God revealed His goodness to one whom He chose. This is the same in the deliverance of Israel from their Egyptian bondage. God had rained plague after plague upon Egypt so that Pharaoh would eventually let the Israelites go. The final plague was the hardest strike on Egypt and the false gods they worshipped. The Egyptian idols were proven useless in protecting their patrons in the disasters, and now even their firstborn were taken. On the other hand, the Israelites who had their doorposts smeared with blood from the lamb were passed over in this final plague. God had mercy upon the Israelites not because there was something inherently deserving in them, for if any had decided not to follow God's instructions and go through the plague without the blood of the lamb, their firstborn would surely have been killed as well. The truth is that God graciously worked faith in the hearts of the believing ones, and salvation was only possible by faith through the blood. Being justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus: Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in his blood, to declare his righteousness for the remission of sins that are past, through the forbearance of God. - Romans 3:24-25

3 JUNE.part7: For he saith to Moses, I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion.  THOUGHT  et us consider further the Old Testament origins of this passage, Exodus 33:19. The Israelites had witnessed great miracles from God - from the ten plagues to the parting of the Red Sea. They experienced the provision of manna every day but one in the week, and yet when Moses was up on Mount Sinai receiving God's instructions, they allowed their imaginations to run wild and made a golden calf to worship. For this great sin, they suffered punishment and three thousand perished. We then read in Exodus 32:31-32 that Moses made an unusual request: "And Moses returned unto the LORD, and said, Oh, this people have sinned a great sin, and have made them gods of gold. Yet now, if thou wilt forgive their sin; and if not, blot me, I pray thee, out of thy book which thou hast written." Moses was willing to suffer eternal punishment on behalf of the people. The psalmist records: "Therefore he said that he would destroy them, had not Moses his chosen stood before him in the breach, to turn away his wrath, lest he should destroy them" [Psalm 106:23]. Moses with his limited knowledge did not know that this was impossible. No sinful mortal can suffer God's wrath vicariously for another - no matter how willing he was. We can only pay for our own sins. This points us to the One who could die in propitiation for all our sins - the Lord Jesus Christ. "For he hath made him to be sin for us, who knew no sin; that we might be made the righteousness of God in him" [2 Corinthians 5:21]. Moses was able to plead on behalf of his people, but only the sacrifice of Jesus Christ, who is the very God Himself, can save us from our unrighteousness. Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by Me. - John 14:6

4 JUNE.part3: VERSE 15 for such a person to realise that man at his best is
4 JUNE.part7: For he saith to Moses, I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion.  THOUGHT  f God has absolute prerogative in showing mercy and compassion to whomsoever He chooses, what then is the role of man? There are at least three things we need to do. Firstly, we should realise we need mercy. The fact that we need God's pardon might sound unpalatable to the natural man who has confidence in his own ways. Brought up in a world that focuses on man's own wisdom and strength, it is difficult for such a person to realise that man at his best is nothing without God and bound for hell. Solely by God's grace does His Spirit work in us, so that our hearts are softened to understand our condition. Next, we should call upon God for mercy. Sometimes God allows circumstances in life to bring us to our knees, and if this is the case, thank God for giving us this opportunity to walk closer with Him. Better a temporal pain here and now than the eternal suffering of hell. "For I know the thoughts that I think toward you, saith the LORD, thoughts of peace, and not of evil, to give you an expected end. Then shall ye call upon me, and ye shall go and pray unto me, and I will hearken unto you. And ye shall seek me, and find me, when ye shall search for me with all your heart." [Jeremiah 29:11-13] Finally, we need to tell others of God's mercy. It is true that God has chosen those whom He will have compassion on, but the counsel of God also tells us He works through unworthy vessels, which we are, to spread the Gospel. Understanding God's mercy to us must cause us to be merciful to others, and through our actions and deeds, tell others about His saving grace. But go ye and learn what that meaneth, I will have mercy, and not sacrifice: for I am not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance. - Matthew 9:13

5 JUNE.part7: So then it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy.  THOUGHT  od's plan of salvation for man, from beginning to end, is all of His grace, which is to say, man has not even the least part in it, otherwise it is no more grace alone but grace plus works. Man on his own will never seek after God for it is written, "There is none that understandeth, there is none that seeketh after God" [Romans 3:11]. Man may be religious but human nature is so totally depraved and corrupt that he only seeks after a god of his own fancy that fits his imagination. He is selfish and idolatrous. The holy God who demands repentance from sin, obedience to His commandments, and faith in Jesus Christ as their only Saviour is a "hard thing" to accept. "This is an hard saying; who can hear it?" [John 6:60] What then, did I not exercise my free will and made the (right) decision to accept God's terms of salvation? Man is spiritually dead [Genesis 2:1617] and can never respond to God, who is a spirit, unless spiritual life is given him. "Behold, I will cause breath to enter into you, and ye shall live" [Ezekiel 37:5b], then shall man begin to call upon God through the preaching of the Gospel. Spurgeon wrote that if you see a piece of dead metal moving on the table, you can be sure there is a hand moving a magnet beneath it. Likewise, with us who were once spiritually dead but made alive again through faith in Christ Jesus. It is the Spirit of God moving and working in us, drawing us near to Him each day.  No man can come to Me, except the Father which hath sent Me draw him. - John 6:44a

6 JUNE.part7: So then it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy.  THOUGHT  race is God bestowing upon us the gifts and blessings that we do not deserve. Mercy is God withholding from us the punishment and judgment that we deserve. As sinners, we do not deserve forgiveness of sin, peace with God, joy of salvation and eternal life in Christ Jesus. Judicially, we deserve God's wrath and justice, separation from Him and eternal damnation in hell. Before the presence of the thrice holy God, we are a "huge mass of corruption", filthy and abominable in His sight. Our righteousness are as filthy rags before Him, how much worse must be our unrighteousness! From the sole of our feet to the crown of our head, we are blemished with wounds and bruises and putrifying sores, which have not been closed, neither bound up, neither mollified with ointment, disgusting and hateful in His sight. The filthiness of the flesh is made manifest in Galatians 5:19-21: "adultery, fornication, uncleanness, lasciviousness, idolatry, witchcraft, hatred, variance, emulations, wrath, strife, seditions, heresies, envyings, murders, drunkenness, revellings, and such like: of the which I tell you before, as I have also told you in time past, that they which do such things shall not inherit the kingdom of God." Who then can be saved? It is God who shows mercy. It is His prerogative to show mercy to whoever He delights in [v. 15]. The fact that we were brought under the sound of the Gospel is God's grace and mercy toward us. See that we are not so dull of hearing nor be sleeping the sleep of death. Who is a God like unto thee, that pardoneth iniquity, and passeth by the transgression of the remnant of his heritage? he retaineth not his anger for ever, because he delighteth in mercy. - Micah 7:18

7 JUNE.part7: So then it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy.  he redemption plan for man is the work of the triune Godhead. Theologians derived from scriptures that God the Father is the author of His redemptive plan, God the Son executed the plan, God the Holy Spirit reveals the plan and applies it to the hearts of sinners. The writer to the Hebrews called this "so great salvation" [Hebrews 2:3], "which things the angels desire to look into" [1 Peter 1:12]. In the words of hymn writer Charles Wesley, 'Tis mystery all! The Immortal dies!, Who can explore His strange design? In vain the firstborn seraph tries to sound the depths of love Divine! 'Tis mercy all! let earth adore, let angel minds inquire no more. The Son of God was made flesh and dwelt among man that He might be the Saviour of mankind. Adam disobeyed God and sinned, bringing the curse of sin and death upon all. But Christ came to save His people from their sins [Matthew 1:21]. He lived to teach them His righteousness, He died to take away their sin, He rose again (from the dead) for their justification. The holy and just God must judge sinners. Unless the offence of sin is satisfactorily resolved, the sinner stands guilty and condemned before his Creator, the Judge of the earth. So, "neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved" [Acts 4:12], but the name of Jesus. No sin is too great for God to forgive. "Let the wicked forsake his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts: and let him return unto the LORD, and He will have mercy upon him; and to our God, for He will abundantly pardon" [Isaiah 55:7].
