8 JUNE.part3: VERSE 17 and "the Scripture saith'. Indeed, we all regard the
8 JUNE.part7: For the scripture saith unto Pharaoh, Even for this same purpose have I raised thee up, that I might shew my power in thee, and that my name might be declared throughout all the earth.  THOUGHT  t is notable that even though the Bible was not yet written in the time that the Israelites were slaves in Egypt, Paul chooses to use the phrase "The Scripture saith". Cross-referencing Exodus 9:13-16, we see that Romans 9:17 is Paul quoting what God had said to Pharaoh through Moses His servant. This gives us some insight into the mind of Paul and how he regarded Scripture. For Paul, there was no difference between what "God saith" and "the Scripture saith". Indeed, we all regard the Bible as the Word of God. Yet, oftentimes we may not live in a manner that demonstrates this. Let us examine ourselves and reflect on the following. First, do we enjoy reading the Bible or find it a chore? Dear Christian, if we profess to be God's children who love Him, then we should derive utmost enjoyment from hearing our Father's voice speaking to us from the pages of His Word. Second, how do we deal with difficult passages in the Bible? Romans 9:17-18 teaches a truth some may find difficult to swallow. We readily accept verses which speak of the mercy and grace of God. However, Paul here emphasises the point that God's raising of Pharaoh, only to harden his heart was also for God's glory. Yes, the hardening of one's heart may also be an act of God's judgment. It is vital that we do not fall into the trap of allowing our biases to distort our understanding of how God works. Let us not downplay what He says.  Am I picking and choosing what parts of the Bible to believe?

9 JUNE.part7: Therefore hath he mercy on whom he will have mercy, and whom he will he hardeneth.  THOUGHT  et us remember that God's hardening of Pharoah's heart was to let His name be glorified in all the earth through the display of His power [v. 17]. As the Sovereign Creator, He has the freedom to save whom He would and to judge those He would. When we consider the purposes of evangelism, we often think the reason we evangelize is to help point others to God through Christ so that souls may be saved. That is not wrong. However, we must also remember that there is an even higher purpose to evangelism. Just as all creation was brought into being to glorify God, the ultimate goal of evangelism is similarly to glorify God. God's sovereignty is glorified during evangelism whether or not the listener professes a desire to receive Christ. Just as God was glorified through the awesome display of His power each time Pharaoh hardened his heart, He will also be glorified when the time for all mankind to be judged comes, even through those who have hardened their hearts. Salvation is entirely God's gift. Let us respond in grateful adoration to Him. As Christians, we glorify God by remembering our entire dependency on Him. We consider our sinfulness, and how Christ loves us and continues to intercede for us in heaven. This must produce a thankful heart that constantly gives praise and glory to God as well as motivate us to live a life well-pleasing to Him.  Roll back the curtain of memory now and then, show me where you brought me from and where I could have been. Lord, I'm weak and human, and humans forget, so remind me, remind me dear Lord.

10 JUNE.part2: Why Doth He Yet Find Fault
10 JUNE.part7: Thou wilt say then unto me, Why doth he yet find fault? For who hath resisted his will?  THOUGHT  espite Paul's assertion of God's sovereignty, there are still many who find that a bitter pill to swallow. Many individuals will continue to try and poke holes in this doctrine seeking to find a way to make God responsible for the fact that they will eventually be condemned to eternal death. Ironically, many such individuals will then go on to profess that it is precisely because of this perceived "unfairness" that they choose not to believe in Him, sealing their eternal fates even though the solution had been presented to them. Let us consider the idea of "finding fault". We seek to assign blame when we feel we are the wronged party. This is why many unbelievers are quick to blame God for allowing the existence of suffering in this world. However, can we really consider ourselves as being "wronged"? Let us realise that in God's eyes, we are all sinners who deserve punishment. Any calamity that befalls us is therefore fitting punishment. Even if there are hardcore atheists who do not accept God's Word as the standard for their living and therefore claim they do not deserve the pain of suffering, they are still guilty on account of their own self-destructive tendencies. They often fail their own standards of morality and engage in activities that harm their own body (example: illicit sex, overeating, drinking, smoking, etc). How can they then claim it is God's obligation to take better care of them than they are taking care of themselves?  It is self-pity to blame God for the consequences of my own sinful nature.

11 JUNE.part7: Thou wilt say then unto me, Why doth he yet find fault? For who hath resisted his will?  THOUGHT  imilar to yesterday's discussion on finding fault with God, many individuals argue for diminished responsibility for their sins on the grounds of God's will. They claim God had willed them to sin and since the creature has no power to go against the Creator's will, there is therefore no way for them to avoid their sins. The extreme version of this argument extends to salvation itself - if God has elected them to destruction, how then can they be blamed for choosing not to believe in God? The answer to such a statement is the same - stop looking at yourself as an innocent party. It would be unjust for a just and holy God to condemn a sinless man to eternal damnation. Because none are sinless, God is therefore just to condemn sinners. When we have such discussions with unbelievers, it often becomes academic at this point and winning the highly theoretical argument here is very unlikely to turn the unsaved person to Christ. Instead, take a more practical approach to provide more salvation opportunities and help the unsaved person acknowledge his own sinful and self-destructive nature. Instead of trying to dictate what God should and should not be doing for all individuals, will the person believe in Christ himself/herself ? By refusing and resisting God's will for him/her to be saved, the unbeliever may realise his own self-destructive nature because though they were offered a way out, they chose not to take it. Yet, and more personally, think of how we got to know Christ - how God worked miraculously in our lives to turn us from our sinful ways. We are who we are only by God's grace. Ask God for patience in doing His works in His ways. It is pride to want to dictate how God should act to save sinners.

12 JUNE.part7: Nay but, O man, who art thou that repliest against God? Shall the thing formed say to him that formed it, Why hast thou made me thus?  THOUGHT  Why is God doing this to me?" We often hear people complaining that God is unfair and questioning, even blaming God. Many still question the basis on which God elects those to be saved. Sinners can never comprehend the doctrine of election. Romans 9:20 provides the answer. Election is God's sovereign choice to save those He elects in His mercy, not by their merit nor any work of man. The words "O man" contrast you and me, the creatures, with God, the creator of all things. Who are we to talk back to God who created us? Apostle Paul intends to put us in our proper place as it is ridiculous for finite man to comprehend and question the infinite God. He rebukes those who do so as being rebellious, arrogant and stubborn. They are not in any position to question God's sovereign acts nor able to understand God's eternal perspective. God is not obligated to tell us what He is doing, whom He chooses to save, and how He decides on things. In fact, our finite minds will never be able to comprehend, "for My thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways My ways, saith the LORD." [Isaiah 55:8]. God only requires us to obey and trust Him. He desires that we submit to and love Him with all our heart, soul and mind. Rather than questioning God's will for our lives, we should shift our perspective to living life every day according to His revealed will for us in order to please Him. May God help us to centre our thoughts and actions around Him. I know that thou canst do every thing, and that no thought can be withholden from thee. Who is he that hideth counsel without knowledge? therefore have I uttered that I understood not; things too wonderful for me, which I knew not ... Wherefore I abhor myself, and repent in dust and ashes. - Job 42:2-6

13 JUNE.part7: Nay but, O man, who art thou that repliest against God? Shall the thing formed say to him that formed it, Why hast thou made me thus?  PRAYER  t is absurd and foolish of man to blame God. Human beings who are created by God cannot challenge the Creator. God has the right and freedom to operate in any way He wishes. "The thing formed" cannot complain about God's creative work and question His salvation plan. God reserves the right to show mercy to some and not others. But Paul reminds us here that whoever objects to God's sovereignty is a fool. As sinners, we do not deserve God's mercy or grace. We are subject to God's power and wrath, and ultimately will face eternal death if we do not repent and turn to Him. God, the creator of the universe, has always been merciful and loving. We cannot see the whole of God's plan but we know God is love [1 John 4:8]. We know God cares for us [Isaiah 44:2], that "the LORD that made thee, and formed thee from the womb will help thee". God's eternal purpose began way before the creation of the universe. Instead of charging God with our foolish accusations, we should use our energy to reflect and examine our minds. Are we living as we should as God's creation? Do we pray, think and act in accordance with God's will? Do we spend enough time meditating on God's Word and communicating with Him through prayer? Be still and hear the voice of the Lord. Let us focus on growing spiritually, and ask God to mould our lives, shape our minds and use our talents for His glory.  O Lord my God, thank You for giving me the peace and assurance that You love me and will deliver me. Show me Thy way and Thy will in me. Amen. "For I know the thoughts that I think toward you, saith the LORD, thoughts of peace, and not of evil, to give you an expected end" [Jeremiah 29:11].

14 JUNE.part3: VERSE 21 the potter at work with a lump of clay. He stood
14 JUNE.part7: Hath not the potter power over the clay, of the same lump to make one vessel unto honour, and another unto dishonour?  PRAYER  Hath not the potter power over the clay?" Here, the apostle Paul uses a prophetic image, the metaphor of the potter and the clay, to illustrate the relationship between the human life and God. In the Old Testament, four messages use the analogy of the potter and the clay: three in Isaiah [Isaiah 29:16; 45:9a; 64:8], and the best-known passage in Jeremiah 18:1-11. Jeremiah at the potter's house had watched the potter at work with a lump of clay. He stood entranced by the spectacle of the workman's subtlety and skill, and heard a Divine voice that said, "Behold, as the clay is in the potter's hand, so are ye in mine hand, O house of Israel" [Jeremiah 18:6b]. More than once in his book, Isaiah had called upon God to reveal Himself in His omnipotence. "We are the clay, and thou our potter; and we all are the work of thy hand." [Isaiah 64:8b]. Paul is arguing God's divine prerogative for the admission of Gentiles as well as Jews into the church of Christ. To the person who complains that God is unjust, Paul responds, "Nay but, O man, who art thou that repliest against God? Shall the thing formed say to him that formed it, Why hast thou made me thus? Hath not the potter power over the clay ... " [v. 20-21a]. The potter claims absolute right in dealing with the lump of clay as he thinks fit, either making it a vessel unto honour, or one unto dishonour. Paul uses the actions of the potter to provide a striking analogy for God's dealing with His people. God formed out of fallen mankind two sorts of vessels - vessels of wrath prepared for destruction [v. 22] and vessels of mercy prepared for glory [v. 23]. Instead of objecting to God's actions, let us heed them and allow our knowledge of judgment and mercy drive us to the repentance we need. O divine Potter, mould me into the image of Jesus my Saviour, Redeemer and Lord. May my life reflect His purity, goodness and grace.

15 JUNE.part7: Hath not the potter power over the clay, of the same lump to make one vessel unto honour, and another unto dishonour?  THOUGHT  od created humans in His own image - we are clay "of the same lump". With the fall of Adam and Eve, humankind also fell into sin - this is how things happened chronologically. But God, who is infinite, works both in and outside time. Therefore, it is also accurate to say that one vessel from the same lump will eventually be unto honour, whereas another unto dishonour. Election is the active work of God saving some to eternal life, and reprobation is God allowing others to perish in their sins. From beginning to end, the potter has every right and power over the clay. More importantly, what kind of vessels are we? Made unto honour or made unto dishonour? Saved or perished? Though everything is in God's sovereign hand, we can ask ourselves some questions. Our answers to these questions are not the conditions for our salvation; however, they are signs of our salvation. The first question to ask is, do you love God and the things of God or is your mind all set on pursuing the things of this world? How can you then demand God to love you, if you do not love Him? God has time and again shown to you His existence and goodness, why is it that you refuse to consider your ways and turn your heart to Him? The sad truth is many people love the gift but not the Giver. They are quick to claim eternal life and all the benefits that come with it, both in this life and the next, yet they refuse to surrender themselves to Christ, as both their Saviour and Lord. We should love the Lord Jesus for Who He is and what He has done for us, consecrating our lives and love to Him. Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world. If any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him. - 1 John 2:15

16 JUNE.part7: Hath not the potter power over the clay, of the same lump to make one vessel unto honour, and another unto dishonour?  THOUGHT  o we love God? Loving God is one clear indication that you are a vessel made unto honour. Your focus is on Him and not yourself. God has clearly said, "For them that honour me I will honour, and they that despise me shall be lightly esteemed" [1 Samuel 2:30]. If we put the kingdom and righteousness of God first in our lives, He will add unto us everything that we need [Matthew 6:33]. The second question to ask ourselves is, do we love others? Do we consider the interest of others or only our own? Are we just and merciful in our dealings with others? Are we good testimonies, leading others to Christ through our example or is our behaviour a stumbling block to those who want to know more about the faith? Our deeds and works either lead people to Christ or drive them away from Him. It is apparent that a vessel made unto honour will be one used by God to bless others. One more question we should ask ourselves is, do we love our own souls? Are we careful in keeping our hearts from the ways of the world? Do we seize every opportunity to grow spiritually - reading and hearing God's Word, praying for others and enjoying loving fellowship with one another? Or do we allow our hearts to be enticed by the attractions of this world, leading us away from God? Indeed, the Potter has absolute power over the clay, but that should further motivate us to give diligence in making our calling and election sure [2 Peter 1:10]. For God, who commanded the light to shine out of darkness, hath shined in our hearts, to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ. But we have this treasure in earthen vessels, that the excellency of the power may be of God, and not of us. - 2 Corinthians 4:6-7

17 JUNE.part3: VERSE 22 question: "Whatif God..." But this is not followed
17 JUNE.part7: What if God, willing to shew his wrath, and to make his power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of wrath fitted to destruction.  THOUGHT  aul has demonstrated the folly of questioning God's sovereign election. This was in response to the objection [v. 19], which suggests that God is unfair to hold us accountable when He has already made the decision. Now Paul continues with the second part of his response to the question in verse 19. Paul begins with what seems like a hypothetical question: "What if God ... " But this is not followed by a direct answer. What is the consequence should the condition, the "if ", be met? Paul did not say. It is precisely through this unstated outcome that Paul brings out the sovereignty of God. God is Who He is, the eternal and holy God, the almighty Creator and sovereign ruler of all. His wisdom is infinite, His ways are unsearchable, His love is unchangeable, and His designs are gracious and good. We are but sinners and creatures. Who are we to question His divine prerogative to deal with us as He deems fit? Who are we to talk back to God or to contend with Him? Rather, we should like Job, put our hands over our mouths and confess that we speak of things that we do not understand, abhor ourselves, and repent in dust and ashes. Let us be still before our all-powerful, wise, and good God. Let us humbly acknowledge His infinite greatness and submit to Him. It is our duty and privilege to trust Him - His perfections, promises, and Word. In all things, He will be glorified.  Be still, and know that I am God: I will be exalted among the heathen, I will be exalted in the earth. - Psalm 46:10

18 JUNE.part3: VERSE 22 tells us that God revealed His wrath against all
18 JUNE.part7: What if God, willing to shew his wrath, and to make his power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of wrath fitted to destruction.  THOUGHT  he next part of the verse deals with God's wrath. God patiently puts up with sinners, vessels of wrath, because He desires to make known His wrath and power. The full measure of His wrath and power will be displayed at the final judgment. The doctrine of God's wrath has been introduced earlier in the epistle. Romans 1:18 tells us that God revealed His wrath against all ungodliness and unrighteousness. This wrath is God's just and right response to sin. He cannot be holy and just if He were to condone evil and let sinners go unpunished. His wrath is poured out in proportion to human sinfulness [Romans 2:5]. It is to be feared because all are guilty and condemned sinners apart from Christ [Romans 3:23]. Why does God desire to show His wrath and power? For His glory. Whether sinners receive their just punishment before an all-powerful and holy God, or whether they are objects of His mercy and grace, God is glorified. Indeed, God's wrath makes the Gospel of grace all the more glorious. The severity of His wrath helps us see the seriousness of sin and comprehend the magnitude of His love and mercy in Christ, for the wrath that should have been poured upon us, guilty and condemned sinners, has been transferred upon and satisfied by Christ. Even as we fear and stand in awe of His wrath, let us take refuge in the precious Gospel of Christ, glorifying and praising God both for His wrath and for His mercy. God's wrath in the Bible is never the capricious, self-indulgent, irritable, morally ignoble thing that human anger so often is. It is, instead, a right and necessary reaction to objective moral evil. - J. I. Packer

19 JUNE.part3: VERSE 22 God demonstrates His power to fulfil all His
19 JUNE.part7: What if God, willing to shew his wrath, and to make his power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of wrath fitted to destruction.  THOUGHT  od desires to make His power known. Indeed, God has revealed Himself to be the omnipotent God, with power over all things, at all times, and in all ways. In Scripture, we learn how God created everything from nothing by the power of His Word. In nature, we see His power to preserve and sustain His creation, keeping the entire universe in perfect balance. Through history, God demonstrates His power to fulfil all His purpose. No one and nothing can thwart God's plans. Earlier in verse 17, Paul tells us that God raised Pharaoh up so that His power might be displayed in Pharaoh and God's name proclaimed in all the earth. Ultimately, all opposition and evil only serve to display God's omnipotence. For these, God's power is to be feared because the full measure of God's wrath and power will be poured out on them at the final judgment. For believers, God's power brings comfort and hope because God is able to do all He has promised. He is able to save all who put their faith in Christ [Romans 1:16]. He is able to keep us from falling [Jude 24]. With God, nothing shall be impossible [Luke 1:37]. His power is the assurance of our salvation. So let us keep trusting God. Trust Him in His power to save and to do all that He has promised. Let us also proclaim His power, so that He may be glorified, and His name praised in all the earth.  Thine, O LORD is the greatness, and the power, and the glory, and the victory, and the majesty: for all that is in the heaven and in the earth is Thine; Thine is the kingdom, O LORD, and Thou art exalted as head above all. - 1 Chronicles 29:11

20 JUNE.part3: VERSE 22 humanity and initiated the covenant of grace. God
20 JUNE.part7: What if God, willing to shew his wrath, and to make his power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of wrath fitted to destruction.  THOUGHT  n verse 22, we see another attribute of God - His longsuffering. To be longsuffering is to exercise self-restraint when provoked. A person who is longsuffering is not quick to retaliate or punish but patiently forebears. We see God's longsuffering in Scripture, in history, and in our lives. When Adam and Eve fell into sin, God did not destroy them straight away. He chose to bear patiently with sinful humanity and initiated the covenant of grace. God patiently tolerated the murmurings and rebellion of Israel in the wilderness, the unfaithfulness of His people in the Promised Land, the rejection of His Son Jesus Christ, the opposition to His church and the persecution of His people. Even when God brought judgment upon the wicked, his judgments were often preceded by much warning and tempered with mercy. Now, God continues to be longsuffering toward us sinners. He patiently forebears for the greater purpose of working out His sovereign plan according to His perfect timing, so that the fullness of His glory and power may be displayed at the consummation of His plan. Just as God is longsuffering with us, He wants us to be longsuffering with others. We cannot be longsuffering toward others by our own strength. Our patience is fleeting compared to God's and we become frustrated easily. Longsuffering is a fruit of the Spirit [Galatians 5:22-23]. It is only when we experience His patience and mercies towards us and submit to Him that we can be vessels of God's patience towards others. Put on therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, bowels of mercies, kindness, humbleness of mind, meekness, longsuffering; forbearing one another, and forgiving one another, if any man have a quarrel against any: even as Christ forgave you, so also do ye. - Colossians 3:12-13

21 JUNE.part3: VERSE 22 just as God brought judgment by water in the days
21 JUNE.part7: What if God, willing to shew his wrath, and to make his power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of wrath fitted to destruction.  THOUGHT  hy is God longsuffering towards sinners? Verse 22 tells us that God forebears with the wicked and allows their sins to accumulate so that the full measure of His wrath and power might be displayed when He judges them at the end. That is however not the only reason. Peter gives another reason in 2 Peter 3:9. The context for this verse is that there are scoffers who mock the promise of Christ's return. Peter reminds them that just as God brought judgment by water in the days of Noah, God will bring a greater judgment upon the wicked by fire when Christ returns. God is not slack in fulfilling His promise. Christ's second return has not yet occurred because God "is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance." God patiently endures our sins and restrains His wrath to allow time for those whom He has elected to repent and come to faith in Christ. Indeed, "the longsuffering of our Lord is salvation" [2 Peter 3:15]. God's longsuffering will not continue forever. It will cease. The final judgment will come, and the full measure of God's wrath will be poured forth. The only way to flee this wrath to come is to repent and believe in Jesus. Have you repented? If not, do not delay. Do not presume on God's kindness and longsuffering. Do not harden your heart. Now is the day of salvation, so that we are ready to say, "Even so, come, Lord Jesus."  For He is our God; and we are the people of His pasture, and the sheep of His hand. To day if ye will hear His voice, harden not your heart, as in the provocation, and as in the day of temptation in the wilderness. - Psalm 95:7-8

22 JUNE.part7: And that he might make known the riches of his glory on the vessels of mercy, which he had afore prepared unto glory,  THOUGHT  od has prepared beforehand, individuals for mercy to make His glory known. While God justly hands the people who reject Him over to destruction, He has also prepared believers to demonstrate His glory through His mercy to them. God prepared hell and eternal judgment for "the devil and his angels" [Matthew 25:41]. Fallen and unrepentant sinners march into hell on account of their sin and rejection of the offer of free grace from God. In His dealing with the elect, God's delay in judging sin and wickedness is because He is longsuffering. Peter says that "the Lord is not slack concerning His promise (of judgment), as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance" [2 Peter 3:9]. God's longsuffering is seen in His many pleas to the people. "I have set before you life and death, blessing and cursing: therefore choose life, that both thou and thy seed may live" [Deuteronomy 30:19]. To the house of Israel, God said, "I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked; but that the wicked turn from his way and live: turn ye, turn ye from your evil ways; for why will ye die, O house of Israel?" [Ezekiel 33:11]. Tragically, the world misreads the longsuffering of God as His unwillingness or His impotence to judge sin thoroughly. Far from it, God's longsuffering is a hallmark of His sovereign mercy so that if a sinner is saved, it is all due to the work of God, and if a sinner is condemned, it is all due to his wilful rebellion, and he cannot blame God for His lack of longsuffering. Sanctification is the preparation of the soul for glory.

To CompLtete THE BiBLeE In 2 YEARS, READ DEUTERONOMY 26 PSALM 119:25-48
23 JUNE.part7: And that he might make known the riches of his glory on the vessels of mercy, which he had afore prepared unto glory, Even us, whom he hath called, not of the Jews only, but also of the Gentiles?  THOUGHT  he glory of God's mercy shines most brilliantly against the dark backdrop of man's sin. Believers are God's chosen vessels of mercy. John Piper writes that the Christian is called out of spiritual deadness and sinful darkness into salvation by mercy, through mercy, and for mercy. He adds, "By mercy, because in our rebellion we do not deserve to be awakened and opened and subdued to God. Through mercy, because every influence that worked on us to bring us to Christ was a mercy from God. For mercy, because every enjoyment that we will ever have ... will be a merciful enjoyment." As vessels of His mercy, we see "the light of the glorious gospel of Christ" [2 Corinthians 4:4]. We, Gentiles, are given "the unsearchable riches of Christ" [Ephesians 3:8]. And in the ages to come, we will see the "exceeding riches of (God's) grace in his kindness toward us through Christ Jesus" [Ephesians 2:7]. When we realise we are vessels of mercy, it means that all the blessings we enjoy are undeserved. This is humbling if you are a believer, and it is unspeakable hope if you are an unbeliever. Perchance you are wondering as you read, "I am not sure if I am one of God's elect. And how do I know that I am a vessel of God's mercy." Paul's answer is: "There is no difference between the Jew and the Greek: for the same Lord over all is rich unto all that call upon Him. For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved" [Romans 10:12-13]. That is God's abounding in riches for you! If God were to have chosen those who were worthy of His salvation, He would have chosen none.

24 JUNE.part7: As he saith also in Osee, I will call them my people, which were not my people; and her beloved, which was not beloved.  THOUGHT  ecause the tribes of Israel were guilty of "great whoredom, departing from the LORD" [Hosea 1:2], God told Hosea to marry a woman who was going to be unfaithful to him. So, Hosea married Gomer [Hosea 1:3-9]. Their first child was named "Jezreel", referring to "the motion of scattering to the wind or throwing away". Their second was named "Lo-Ruhamah", meaning "Not-Loved" or "Not-Pitied". Their third child was named "Lo-Ammi", meaning "Not-MyPeople". The names of Hosea's children illustrated God's punishment for an unfaithful people. The time came when Gomer left Hosea. She fell into slavery and was auctioned in Samaria. Hosea was instructed to go and buy her back. He bid a high price, and she was his once more. If Hosea had hated Gomer, he could have chosen to kill her or abandon her for the pain she had caused him. Instead, Hosea promised to be a faithful husband to her as he had been, while now demanding faithfulness from her in return. Symbolically, the names of Hosea's children were changed to illustrate God's mercy. Jezreel would now mean "to be planted" instead of "scattered". The negative prefix in "Lo-Ruhamah" would be eliminated to become "Ruhamah", or "Loved", because God would have love and pity on the people again. "LoAmmi" would become "Ammi", or "My People". When Jesus was crucified, He too responded not with anger towards His punishers. Instead, when they nailed Him to the cross and cast lots for His raiments, Jesus pleaded with God to forgive them, "for they know not what they do" [Luke 23:34]. Consider what Christ has done for you in purchasing you from slavery by His own blood. Should we not love Him with all our heart, mind and soul?

25 JUNE.part7: As he saith also in Osee, I will call them my people, which were not my people; and her beloved, which was not beloved.  THOUGHT  he tribes of Israel were so degenerate that by their wilful rejection of God, He declared them no longer His people. God's rejection meant He would have no special relationship with them and therefore no obligation to them. Once God's people, they had spiralled into an apostate nation living in unbelief. Rightfully did God say, these were "not My people." However, in the same breath, God condescends to these He had called "Not-My-People", and said "Thou art My people" [Hosea 2:23b]. By these successive declarations, God shows us that salvation is by His grace alone and has nothing to do with a person's worthiness or ancestry. Paul's reference to Hosea also emphasises the divine certainty of God's declarations. While Hosea records that God will simply say they are His people, Paul takes it a step further by stressing that God will call them His people. Paul is emphasising the glorious truth of God's effectual call. This is God's sovereign and irresistible call that will always be answered. It is His call that sinners are summoned to come out of darkness into light. It is His call that sinners come out of the darkness of sin into the new life in Jesus Christ. We once lived in darkness and captivity, in spiritual chains of our own sins. God declares to us that He will call us His people. Regardless of who we are, even the most stubborn of hearts will be overcome by God and found willing in the day when He calls us to Himself.  I heard the voice of Jesus say, "Behold, I freely give The living water, thirsty one; Stoop down and drink and live." - John B. Dykes

26 JUNE.part2: The Children of the Living God
26 JUNE.part7: And it shall come to pass, that in the place where it was said unto them, Ye are not my people; there shall they be called the children of the living God.  THOUGHT  esterday, we saw how God, in His marvellous grace and infinite love, called those who were not His people, to become His - children of the living God. Indeed, all of us are undeserving of this grand appellation but rather deserving of His wrath and eternal judgment. Yet, we have been chosen, elect from the beginning of time to be His children: sons and daughters of the one true and living God. In this wonderful title, we learn, firstly, that our God is a living God, unlike other gods that are dead idols. And we who belong to Him, are blessed with the protection of the God who is ever with us, ever watchful over us. Our God is the Creator of the universe, and everything that is in it [Colossians 1:16-17]. He is also the Sustainer of this universe, and without His gracious providence, this universe will descend into chaos and anarchy in a second. So, how does a person come to be a child of God? The Scriptures are unequivocal about this: if you believe Christ died for your sins on Calvary's cross, was raised up again on the third day, and has ascended into Heaven, now seated at the right hand of God, and if you have confessed with your mouth that Christ is your Lord, and believe this in your heart, then you are a child of God. Dear reader, have you believed in Jesus Christ and confessed Him to be your Saviour?  That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved. - Romans 10:9.

27 JUNE.part7: And it shall come to pass, that in the place where it was said unto them, Ye are not my people; there shall they be called the children of the living God.  THOUGHT  ow is it that one comes to believe in this living God? Yesterday we stated that one is called to be a child of God when one truly believes and puts his faith in Jesus Christ and His righteousness, who shed His blood to redeem man from his sins. Yet many of us have attempted and failed to convince our loved ones and friends of this. So, how and why does one come to believe? Firstly, we know from Romans 8:29 that God has chosen those whom He will save. Then verse 30 goes on to say: "Moreover whom he did predestinate, them he also called: and whom he called, them he also justified: and whom he justified, them he also glorified." Apostle Paul, in Romans 8:30, summarizes the process of salvation to eventual glorification of a person. We note that in this process, God is the one who actively calls and enables a person to believe His truth. God is the one who justifies and glorifies him. Therefore, when we share God's truth with anyone, it is not our eloquence, persuasiveness or personality that convinces them to believe in the truth, it is all God's doing. We are just messengers of His message. Therefore, let us humble ourselves before our Lord, and go forth to do His work sharing the Gospel with those around us, knowing that it is God Himself who will work in their hearts to believe and be saved, so that in the end, it is God who is glorified.  For whom He did foreknow, He also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of His Son, that He might be the firstborn among many brethren. - Romans 8:29

28 JUNE.part7: And it shall come to pass, that in the place where it was said unto them, Ye are not my people; there shall they be called the children of the living God.  THOUGHT  esterday we saw that the work of salvation is all of God's doing. Let us consider the implications of being called His children. When a newborn baby is given away for adoption, the adoptive family receives the child as their own to love and raise as their own. The child takes on the family name and is expected to love and be devoted to the adoptive parents as his own. In a similar manner, when one is adopted into God's family, he becomes His child and is expected to love and be devoted to his heavenly Father. We are saved for a purpose, to do God's work. Having received forgiveness and escape from eternal condemnation, can we sit around while others are sliding down the slippery slope to hell and eternal judgment? No. We should rather warn them of the folly and danger of their ways. We must equip ourselves with the tools necessary for God's work, namely the Bible, so that we can be effective servants and soldiers for Christ. It is not an easy road but we can trust Him to see us through by His grace. Serving God and doing His work demands total devotion, and we should not be distracted by the world [Matthew 6:24; Luke 9:62]. Fellow labourers in Christ, are you ready to do God's work? Is your heart totally set on serving the true and living God, as His faithful children?  And Jesus said unto him, No man, having put his hand to the plough, and looking back, is fit for the kingdom of God. - Luke 9:62

29 JUNE.part7: Esaias also crieth concerning Israel, Though the number of the children of Israel be as the sand of the sea, a remnant shall be saved.  THOUGHT  n verses 25-26, Paul quoted prophet Hosea in stating how the Gospel would spread to the Gentiles as a result of the Jews' waywardness. Here, he quotes the prophet Isaiah to remind his readers what happened to Israel. "For though thy people Israel be as the sand of the sea, yet a remnant of them shall return: the consumption decreed shall overflow with righteousness. For the Lord GOD of hosts shall make a consumption, even determined, in the midst of all the land" [Isaiah 10:22-23]. The testimony of Isaiah is firstly a pronouncement of woe. Isaiah prophesied the destruction of Israel. The "consumption" (the finished work of destruction) decreed by God would surely come to pass. God's judgment would be a righteous one and declared to every land for even the justice of God shall tell of His glory. Historically, this would point to the destruction of Judah by the Babylonians when many Israelites were deported to foreign lands. Yet the message of Isaiah also carried hope and promise. A remnant of God's chosen race shall be saved - this alluded to the survivors of the invasion and the small number that would return to Israel 70 years after captivity. From God's perspective, Isaiah was prophesying about the Jews who were spiritually lost and whose end was destruction. But he also reminds us that some shall be saved albeit a remnant. The covenantal promise to Abraham is that his descendants would be like the stars in the heaven and the sand of the sea [Genesis 22:17]. Though a great multitude, most would eventually face destruction. Sadly, only a remnant would be saved. For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek. For therein is the righteousness of God revealed from faith to faith: as it is written, The just shall live by faith. - Romans 1:16-17

THOUGHT  he holy God would never condone sinners to live eternally in His presence. Sin must be punished and God's justice must be met. Yet God is good and gracious - He opened the door of salvation and chose some to be saved through the blood of His only begotten Son. "For ye are all the children of God by faith in Christ Jesus. For as many of you as have been baptized into Christ have put on Christ. There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither bond nor free, there is neither male nor female: for ye are all one in Christ Jesus. And if ye be Christ's, then are ye Abraham's seed, and heirs according to the promise" [Galatians 3:2629]. The only way to salvation is Jesus Christ. Those who believe in Him, Jews and Gentiles alike, are called "Abraham's seed" in that we are spiritual descendants of Abraham and heirs of God's covenantal promises in the Scriptures. And the whole counsel of God is consistent in saying that those who will be saved are only a remnant, according to God's perfect will. Thank God for salvation rich and free. We who were once lost in our sin and trespasses, are revived by His grace, and enjoy the privilege of calling Him "Abba, Father". It pleased God that we would belong to a saved minority. This should not make us self-righteous, but should humble us to live a life of gratitude, praying for God to give us the wisdom and strength to tell this good news to others so that they may also be a part of this remnant. "Know ye that the LORD He is God: it is He that hath made us, and not we ourselves; we are His people, and the sheep of His pasture." [Psalm 100:3] For thou art an holy people unto the LORD thy God: the LORD thy God hath chosen thee to be a special people unto himself, above all people that are upon the face of the earth. - Deuteronomy 7:6
